HP:0009883 ! Duplication of the distal phalanx of hand
children.defn: "Complete or partial duplication of the distal phalanx of the thumb. Depending on the severity, the appearance on x-ray can vary from a notched phalanx (the duplicated bone is almost completely fused with the phalanx), a partially fused appearance of the two bones, or two separate bones appearing side to side." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Duplication of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
is_a_string: HP:0009618 ! Abnormality of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
HP:0010008 ! Duplication of the middle phalanx of hand
children.defn: "Complete or partial duplication of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. Depending on the severity, the appearance on x-ray can vary from a notched phalanx (the duplicated bone is almost completely fused with the phalanx), a partially fused appearance of the two bones, or two separate bones appearing side to side. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits." [HPO:sdoelken]

"Complete or partial duplication of the phalanges of the thumb. Depending on the severity, the appearance on x-ray can vary from a notched phalanx (the duplicated bone is almost completely fused with the phalanx), a partially fused appearance of the two bones (bifid), two separate bones appearing side to side, or completely duplicated phalanges (proximal and distal phalanx of the thumb and/or 1st metacarpal). In contrast to the phalanges of the digits 2-5 (proximal, middle and distal), the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Postaxial hand polydactyly
Postaxial polydactyly type A
children.defn: "Supernumerary digits located at the ulnar side of the hand with a complete extra finger and extra metacarpal." [HPO:probinson]
"Supernumerary digits located at the ulnar side of the hand (that is, on the side with the fifth finger)." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Ectopic accesory finger-like appendage
children.defn: "In contrast to forms of polydactyly where the supernumerary digit (this can either be a rudimentary or a completely 'normal' digit) is either located postaxial (on the ulnar side of the hand, next to the little finger), preaxial (on the radial side of the hand, next to the thumb) or mesoaxial (somewhere central, between thumb and little finger), a supernumerary digit may also be placed ectopically, meaning anywhere else except post-,meso- or preaxial. In the literature this is sometimes refered to as Disorganisation-like Syndrome (OMIM223200)." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Preaxial hand polydactyly
children.defn: "Supernumerary digits located at the radial side of the hand. Polydactyly (supernumerary digits) involving the thumb occurs in many distinct forms of high variability and severity. Ranging from fleshy nubbins over varying degrees of partial duplication/splitting to completely duplicated or even triplicated thumbs or preaxial (on the radial side of the hand) supernumerary digits." [HPO:probinson]

"An abnormal union between bones or parts of bones of the fingers. The synonymous term \"symphalangism of the hand\" may be translated as fusions of bones of varying digree, that involve at least one phalangeal bone of the hand. If bony fusions are revered to as \"Symphalangism\" the fusion occurs in a proximo-distal axis. Fusions of bones of the fingers in a radio-ulnar axis are refered to as \"bony\" Syndactyly." children.name: Hand clenching
children.defn: "An abnormal hand posture in which the hands are clenched to fists. All digits held completely flexed at the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints." [HPO:sdoelken, pmid:10085502]

children.defn: "A finger resting on the dorsal surface of an adjacent digit when the hand is at rest." [HPO:probinson, pmid:19125433]

children.name: Mitten deformity

children.name: Broad 1st metacarpal
is_a_string: HP:0009852 ! Broad proximal phalanges of the hand
children.defn: "Increased width of the 1st metacarapal. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Bullet-shaped 1st metacarpal

children.name: Triangular shaped 1st metacarpal

"A structural anomaly of the first metacarpal." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Y-shaped metacarpals
Central Y-shaped metacarpal
children.defn: "A central Y-shaped metacarpal is the result of a partial fusion of two central metacarpals (i.e., metacarpals 2-4) of the hand, with the two arms of the Y pointing in the distal direction. Central Y-shaped metacarpals may be seen as a result of a central polydactyly with partial fusion of the duplicated metacarpal." [HPO:curators]

"Y-shaped metacarpals are the result of a partial fusion of two metacarpal bones, with the two arms of the Y pointing in the distal direction. Y-shaped metacarpals may be seen in combination with polydactyly." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Slender metacarpals

children.name: Swan neck-like deformities of the fingers
children.defn: "A swan neck deformity describes a finger with a hyperextended PIP joint and a flexed DIP joint. The most common cause for a swan neck-like deformity is a disruption of the end of the extensor tendon. Conditions that loosen the PIP joint and allow it to hyperextend, for example conditions that weaken the volar plate, can produce a swan neck deformity of the finger. One example is rheumatoid arthritis. Another cause are conditions that tighten up the small (intrinsic) muscles of the hand and fingers, for example hand trauma or nerve disorders, such as cerebral palsy, Parkinson's disease, or stroke." [HPO:curators]

"The middle finger is more than 2 SD above the mean for newborns 27 to 41 weeks EGA or above the 97th centile for children from birth to 16 years of age AND the five digits retain their normal length proportions relative to each other (i.e., it is not the case that the middle finger is the only lengthened digit), or, Fingers that appear disproportionately long compared to the palm of the hand." [pmid:19125433]

children.name: Abnormality of the thumb

"An anomaly of the thumb." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Slender finger
children.defn: "Digits are disproportionately narrow (reduced girth) for the hand/foot size or build of the individual." [pmid:19125433]

children.name: Splayed fingers

"An anomaly of a finger." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Abnormality of the palm
Long palm
children.defn: "For children from birth to 16 years of age the length of the palm is more than the 97th centile; or, the length of the palm appears relatively long compared to the finger length or the limb length." [pmid:19125433]

children.name: Narrow palm
children.defn: "For children from birth to 4 years of age, the palm width is more than 2 SD below the mean; for children from 4 to 16 years of age the palm width is below the 5th centile; or, the width of the palm appears disproportionately narrow for its length." [pmid:19125433]

children.name: Broad palm
children.defn: "For children from birth to 4 years of age the palm width is more than 2 SD above the mean; for children from 4 to 16 years of age the palm width is above the 95th centile; or, the width of the palm appears disproportionately wide for the length." [HPO:probinson, pmid:19125433]
"An abnormality of the palm, that is, of the front of the hand." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Split hand
children.defn: "A condition in which middle parts of the hand (fingers and metacarpals) are missing giving a cleft appearance. The severity is very variable ranging from slightly hypoplastic middle fingers over absent middel fingers as far as oligo- or monodactyl hands." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Ulnar claw
children.defn: "An abnormal hand position characterized by hyperextension of the fourth and fifth fingers at the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion of the interphalangeal joints of the same fingers such that they are curled towards the palm." [HPO:probinson]
"An abnormality affecting one or both hands." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Edema of the upper limbs

children.defn: "An abnormal accumulation of fluid beneath the skin of the arms." [HPO:probinson]
"An abnormality of the arm." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Short digit
Brachydactyly syndrome
Type D brachydactyly
children.defn: "This type of brachydactyly is characterized by short and broad terminal phalanges of the thumbs and big toes." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Type E brachydactyly
children.defn: "In type E brachydactyly, shortening of the fingers is mainly in the metacarpals and metatarsals." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Brachytelomesophalangy
children.defn: "Disproportionately short middle and distal phalanges compared to the hand/foot." [HPO:probinson]

"Digits that appear disproportionately short compared to the hand/foot. The word brachydactyly is used to describe a series of Mendelian diseases characterized by distinct patterns of shortened digits (brachydactyly types A-E). This is the sense used here, however, it is preferable to described the observed phenotypic abnormalities precisely." [HPO:probinson]
"One or more digit that appears disproportionately short compared to the hand/foot, whereby either the entire digit or a specific phalanx is shortened." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Macrodactyly
children.defn: "Significant increase in the length and girth of most or all of a digit compared to its contralateral digit (if unaffected) or compared to what would be expected for age/body build. The increased girth is accompanied by an increase in the dorso-ventral dimension AND the lateral dimension of the digit." [pmid:19125433]

children.name: Oligodactyly
children.defn: "A developmental defect resulting in the presence of fewer than the normal number of digits." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Polydactyly
Preaxial polydactyly
children.defn: "A form of polydactyly in which the extra digit or digits are localized on the side of the thumb or great toe." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Postaxial polydactyly
children.defn: "A form of polydactyly in which the extra digit or digits are localized on the side of the fifth finger or fifth toe." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Mirror image polydactyly
children.defn: "A hand or foot with more than five digits that has a recognizable A/P axis of symmetry. The axis can lie within a normally formed or partially duplicated digit resembling a middle finger, index finger, thumb, toe, or hallux. Alternatively, the axis can be in an interdigital space with a flanking pair of digits that resemble a middle finger, index finger, thumb, toe or hallux. The most lateral digits on each side of the hand typically resemble fifth fingers/toes." [HPO:sdoelken, pmid:19125433]

children.name: Mesoaxial polydactyly
children.defn: "The presence of a supernumerary finger or toe (not a thumb or hallux) involving the third or fourth metacarpal/tarsal with associated osseous syndactyly." [pmid:19125433]
"A congenital anomaly characterized by the presence of supernumerary fingers or toes." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Syndactyly
Cutaneous syndactyly
Cutaneous finger syndactyly
3-4 finger cutaneous syndactyly
children.defn: "A soft tissue continuity in the A/P axis between fingers 4 and 4." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Cutaneous syndactyly between fingers 2 and 5
children.defn: "A soft tissue continuity in the anteroposterior axis between the second to the fifth fingers that extends distally to at least the level of the proximal interphalangeal joints." [HPO:probinson]

"A soft tissue continuity in the A/P axis between two fingers that extends distally to at least the level of the proximal interphalangeal joints, or a soft tissue continuity in the A/P axis between two fingers that lies significantly distal to the flexion crease that overlies the metacarpophalangeal joint of the adjacent fingers." [pmid:19125433]

"A soft tissue continuity in the A/P axis between two digits that extends distally to at least the level of the proximal interphalangeal joints, or a soft tissue continuity in the A/P axis between two digits that lies significantly distal to the flexion crease that overlies the metacarpophalangeal or metatarsophalangeal joint of the adjacent digits." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Finger syndactyly
Osseous finger syndactyly
children.defn: "Webbing or fusion of the fingers, involving soft parts and including fusion of individual finger bones. Bony fusions are revered to as \"bony\" Syndactyly if the fusion occurs in a radio-ulnar axis. Fusions of bones of the fingers in a proximo-distal axis are refered to as \"Symphalangism\"." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: 1-2 finger syndactyly
children.defn: "Syndactyly with fusion of fingers one and two." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: 4-5 finger syndactyly
children.defn: "Syndactyly with fusion of fingers four and five." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: 1-3 finger syndactyly
children.defn: "Syndactyly with fusion of fingers one to three." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: 1-4 finger syndactyly
children.defn: "Syndactyly with fusion of fingers one to four." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: 1-5 finger syndactyly
children.defn: "Syndactyly with fusion of fingers one to five (complete syndactyly of all fingers of the hand)." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: 2-4 finger syndactyly
children.defn: "Syndactyly with fusion of the fingers two to four." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: 3-4 finger syndactyly
children.defn: "Syndactyly with fusion of fingers three and four." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: 2-3 finger syndactyly
children.defn: "Syndactyly with fusion of fingers two and three." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: 3-5 finger syndactyly
children.defn: "Syndactyly with fusion of fingers three to five." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: 2-5 finger syndactyly
children.defn: "Syndactyly with fusion of fingers two to five." [HPO:sdoelken]

"Webbing or fusion of the fingers, involving soft parts only or including bone structure. Bony fusions are revered to as \"bony\" Syndactyly if the fusion occurs in a radio-ulnar axis. Fusions of bones of the fingers in a proximo-distal axis are refered to as \"Symphalangism\"." [HPO:curators]

"Webbing or fusion of the fingers or toes, involving soft parts only or including bone structure. Bony fusions are revered to as \"bony\" syndactyly if the fusion occurs in a radio-ulnar axis. Fusions of bones of the fingers or toes in a proximo-distal axis are refered to as \"symphalangism\"." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Clubbing
children.defn: "Broadening of the soft tissues (non-edematous swelling of soft tissues) of the digital tips in all dimensions associated with an increased longitudinal and lateral curvature of the nails." [HPO:sdoelken, pmid:19125433]

children.name: Clinodactyly
children.defn: "An angulation of a digit at an interphalangeal joint in the plane of the palm (finger) or sole (toe)." [pmid:16252026]
"A morphological abnormality of a digit, i.e., of a finger or toe." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Ectrodactyly
is_a_string: HP:0002813 ! Abnormality of limb bone morphology
children.defn: "A condition in which middle parts of the hands and/or feet (digits and meta-carpals and -tarsals) are missing giving a cleft appearance. The severity is very variable ranging from slightly hypoplastic 3rd toe/fingers over absent 2nd or 3rd toes/fingers as far as oligo- or monodactyl hands and/or feet." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Aplasia involving bones of the extremities
is_a_string: HP:0002813 ! Abnormality of limb bone morphology

children.name: Abnormality of the metaphyses
is_a_string: HP:0002813 ! Abnormality of limb bone morphology
HP:0011314 ! Abnormality of long bone morphology

children.name: Metaphyseal sclerosis
Metaphyseal dappling
children.defn: "The presence of spots or rounded patches of abnormally increased density of metaphyseal bone." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Streaky metaphyseal sclerosis
children.defn: "The presence of streaks (bands) of abnormally increased density of metaphyseal bone." [HPO:probinson]
"Abnormally increased density of metaphyseal bone." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Abnormal metaphyseal trabeculation
children.defn: "An abnormality of the pattern of trabecula (small interconnecting rods of bone) in a metaphyseal region of bone." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Enlarged metaphyses
children.defn: "Abnormal increase in size of one or more metaphyses." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Osteopathia striata
is_a_string: HP:0004348 ! Abnormality of bone mineral density
HP:0011314 ! Abnormality of long bone morphology
children.defn: "A lamellar pattern visible on radiographs and mainly localized at the metaphyses of the long tubular bones. Pathologic-anatomical studies revealed that these benign signs on x-rays are the result of a juvenile metaphyseal bone necrosis. Calcifications in the necrotic marrow lead to this lamellar or lattice-like appearance." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Metaphyseal dysplasia
Metaphyseal chondrodysplasia
children.defn: "An abnormality of skeletal development characterized by a disturbance of the metaphysis and its histological structure with relatively normal epiphyses and vertebrae." [HPO:probinson, pmid:335375]
"The presence of dysplastic regions in metaphyseal bones." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Metaphyseal rarefaction
children.defn: "Reduction in density of metaphyseal bony tissue." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Metaphyseal cupping
Metaphyseal cupping of metacarpals
children.defn: "Metaphyseal cupping affecting the metacarpal bones." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Metaphyseal cupping of proximal phalanges
children.defn: "Metaphyseal cupping affecting the proximal phalanges." [HPO:curators]
"Metaphyseal cupping refers to an inward bulging of the metaphyseal profile giving the metaphysis a cup-like appearance." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Metaphyseal irregularity
children.defn: "Irregularity of the normally smooth surface of the metaphyses." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Dense metaphyseal bands
children.defn: "Dense radiopaque bands of bone which are thicker than the adjacent diaphyseal cortex and may form at the metaphysis of growing bones." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Metaphyseal spurs
children.defn: "Bony outgrowths that extend laterally from the margin of the metaphysis." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Metaphyseal widening
Flared metaphyses
children.defn: "The presence of splayed (i.e.,flared) metaphyseal segments of the long bones." [HPO:probinson, pmid:12853662]

children.name: Dumbbell-shaped long bone
is_a_string: HP:0011314 ! Abnormality of long bone morphology

children.name: Dumbbell-shaped humerus
children.defn: "The humerus is shortened and displays flaring (widening) of the metaphyses." [HPO:probinson]

"An abnormal appearance of the long bones with resemblance to a dumbbell, a short bar with a weight at each end. That is, the long bone is shortened and displays flaring (widening) of the metaphyses." [HPO:probinson]
"Abnormal widening of the metaphyseal regions of long bones." [HPO:probinson]
"An abnormality of one or more metaphysis, i.e., of the somewhat wider portion of a long bone that is adjacent to the epiphyseal growth plate and grows during childhood." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Abnormality involving the epiphyses of the limbs

children.defn: "A detrimental reaction to the presence of gluten in food, which may include abdominal pain, fatigue, headaches and paresthesia, or celiac disease." [HPO:probinson]

"A detrimental reaction to a food, beverage, food additive, or compound found in foods that produces symptoms in one or more body organs and systems that is not mediated by an immune reaction." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Abnormality of temperature regulation
Fever
Low-grade fever
children.defn: "Mild fever that does not exceed 38.5 degree centrigrade." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Unexplained fevers
children.defn: "Episodes of fever for which no infectious cause can be identified." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Episodic fever
children.defn: "Periodic (episodic or recurrent) bouts of fever." [HPO:probinson]
"Elevated body temperature due to failed thermoregulation." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Temperature instability
children.defn: "Disordered thermoregulation characterized by an impaired ability to maintain a balance between heat production and heat loss, with resulting instability of body temperature." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Heat intolerance
children.defn: "The inability to maintain a comfortably body temperature in warm or hot weather." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Malignant hyperthermia
children.defn: "Malignant hyperthermia is characterized by a rapid increase in temperature to 39-42 degrees C in response to inhalational anesthetics such as halothane or to muscle relaxants such as succinylcholine." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Hypothermia

children.defn: "Episodes of reduced body termperature." [HPO:probinson]

"A vestibular Schwannoma (also known as acoustic neuroma, acoustic neurinoma, or acoustic neurilemoma) is a benign, usually slow-growing tumor that develops from the VIIIth cranial nerve supplying the inner ear." [HPO:probinson]

is_a_string: HP:0040095 ! Neoplasm of the outer ear

children.name: Hearing abnormality
Abnormal speech discrimination
children.defn: "A type of hearing impairment prominently characterized by a difficulty in understanding speech, rather than an inability to hear speech. Poor speech discrimination is a very common symptom of high frequency hearing loss." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Tinnitus
Pulsatile tinnitus
children.defn: "Pulsatile tinnitus is generally classified a kind of objective tinnitus, meaning that it is not only audible to the patient but also to the examiner on auscultation of the auditory canal and/or of surrounding structures with use of an auscultation tube or stethoscope. Usually, pulsatile tinnitus is heard as a lower pitched thumping or booming, a rougher blowing sound which is coincidental with respiration, or as a clicking, higher pitched rhythmic sensation. Pulsatile tinnitus may be associated with vascular abnormalities such as arterioevenous shunts or glomus tumors or the jugular vein, arterial bruits related to a high-riding carotid artery (close to the auditory areas) or carotid stenosis, or venous abnormalities such as a dehiscent jugular bulb or to hypertension. Finally, in some patients, mechanical abnormalities such a spatulous eustachian tubes, palatomyoclonus (small spasms of muscles in the soft palate area), or idiopathic stapedial muscle spasm may represent the underlying cause of pulsatile tinnitus." [HPO:curators]
"Tinnitus is an auditory perception that can be described as the experience of sound, in the ear or in the head, in the absence of external acoustic stimulation." [Cochrane:ab005233]

children.name: Hearing impairment
Severe hearing impairment
Severe sensorineural hearing impairment

"A severe form of hearing impairment." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Moderate hearing impairment
Moderate sensorineural hearing impairment

"The presence of a moderate form of hearing impairment." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Mild hearing impairment

children.name: Unilateral deafness

children.name: High-frequency hearing impairment

children.name: Progressive hearing impairment

children.name: Low-frequency hearing loss

children.name: Transient hearing impairment

children.name: Profound hearing impairment

children.name: Lop ear
children.defn: "Anterior and inferior folding of the upper portion of the ear that obliterates triangular fossa and scapha." [HPO:probinson, pmid:19152421]

children.name: Cupped ear
children.defn: "Laterally protruding ear that lacks antihelical folding (including absence of inferior and superior crura)." [HPO:probinson, pmid:19162421]

children.name: Macrotia
children.defn: "Median longitudinal ear length greater than two standard deviations above the mean and median ear width greater than two standard deviations above the mean (objective); or, apparent increase in length and width of the pinna (subjective)." [pmid:19152421]

children.name: Protruding ear
children.defn: "Angle formed by the plane of the ear and the mastoid bone greater than the 97th centile for age (objective); or, outer edge of the helix more than 2 cm from the mastoid at the point of maximum distance (objective)." [pmid:19152421]

children.name: Long ear
children.defn: "Median longitudinal ear length greater than two SD above the mean determined by the maximal distance from the superior aspect to the inferior aspect of the external ear." [eom:2028381d5c61842a, pmid:19152421]

children.name: Short ear
children.defn: "Median longitudinal ear length less than two SD above the mean determined by the maximal distance from the superior aspect to the inferior aspect of the external ear." [eom:2cff5ac9b681fc73, pmid:19152421]

children.name: Crumpled ear

children.name: Calcification of the auricular cartilage

children.name: Abnormality of the antihelix
Prominent antihelix
children.defn: "The presence of an abnormally prominent antihelix." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Hypoplasia of the antihelix
children.defn: "Developmental hypoplasia of the antihelix." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Angulated antihelix

children.name: Absent antihelix

children.name: Antihelical shelf

"Supernumerary ridge or crus of the ear arising from the antihelix." [pmid:19152421]

is_a_string: HP:0011243 ! Abnormality of inferior crus of antihelix

children.name: Prominent inferior crus of antihelix

"An abnormality of the inferior crus of the antihelix is the lower cartilaginous ridge arising at the bifurcation of the antihelix that ends beneath the fold of the ascending helix, and separates the concha from the triangular fossa." [HPO:probinson, pmid:19152421]

children.name: Abnormality of superior crus of antihelix

children.name: Cleft earlobe

children.name: Forward facing earlobe

children.name: Duplicated tragus

children.name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the tragus

children.name: Absent tragus

children.name: Microtia, third degree

children.name: Abnormality of the antitragus

children.name: Bifid antitragus

children.name: Everted antitragus

children.name: Prominent ear helix

children.name: Thin ear helix

children.name: Posterior helix pit

children.name: Long hairs growing from helix of pinna
Overfolded helix

children.defn: "A condition in which the superior portion of the helix is folded over to a greater degree than normal." [HPO:probinson]

"A condition in which the helix is folded over to a greater degree than normal. That is, excessive curling of the helix edge, whereby the free edge is parallel to the plane of the ear." [HPO:probinson, pmid:19152421]

children.name: Cleft helix

Darwin notch of helix

"A notched form of the helix of the ear. That is, a defect in the continuity of the helix, which may occur at any point along its length." [HPO:probinson, pmid:19152421]

children.name: Abnormality of the crus of the helix
Serpiginous crus of helix

children.name: Crus of helix connected to antihelix
is_a_string: HP:0009895 ! Abnormality of the crus of the helix
children.defn: "Extension of the ridge of the crus helix across the ear and connection of the crus to the antihelix." [pmid:19152421]

children.name: Tragal bridge of crus of helix

children.defn: "The anterior origin of the crus encompasses the superior margin of the tragus, the crus overrides the upper portion of the conchal cavum and ends at the antihelix." [pmid:19152421]

children.name: Absent crus of helix

children.name: Expanded terminal portion of crus of helix
is_a_string: HP:0009895 ! Abnormality of the crus of the helix
children.defn: "Widening, rather than tapering, of the crus at its posterior border near the antihelix." [pmid:19152421]

children.name: Underdeveloped crus of the helix
is_a_string: HP:0009895 ! Abnormality of the crus of the helix
children.defn: "Developmental hypoplasia of the crus of the helix (FMA:61024). That is, flatter and/or shorter crus helix than average." [HPO:probinson, pmid:19152421]

children.name: Prominent crus of helix
is_a_string: HP:0009895 ! Abnormality of the crus of the helix
children.defn: "The presence of an abnormally prominent of the crus of the helix (FMA:61024). That is, development of the crus helix to the same degree as an average antihelix stem or helix." [HPO:probinson, pmid:19152421]

children.name: Horizontal crus of helix
is_a_string: HP:0009895 ! Abnormality of the crus of the helix
children.defn: "An abnormal horizontal axis orientation of the crus of the helix (FMA:61024). That is, the main axis of the crus of the helix is perpendicular to the medial longitudinal axis of the ear, instead of sloping inferoposteriorly." [HPO:probinson, pmid:19152421]
"An abnormality of the crus of the helix (FMA:61024), which is the horizontal piece of cartilage located outside the ear canal that divides the upper and lower parts of the ear." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Crimped helix
children.defn: "Linear, circumferential indentation in the convexity of the outer surface of the helix." [pmid:19152421]

children.name: Darwin tubercle of helix
children.defn: "Small expansion of the helical fold at the junction of the superior and descending portions of the helix." [pmid:19152421]

children.name: Squared superior portion of helix
children.defn: "Flattening instead of curving or rounded superior helix, allowing the superior helix to run more horizontally than usual." [eom:ddce48fcd9ee46f4, pmid:19152421]
"An abnormality of the helix. The helix is the outer rim of the ear that extends from the insertion of the ear on the scalp (root) to the termination of the cartilage at the earlobe." [HPO:probinson]
"An abnormality of the pinna, which is also referred to as the auricle or external ear." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Abnormal location of ears
is_a_string: HP:0000356 ! Abnormality of the outer ear

children.name: Posteriorly rotated ears
Low-set, posteriorly rotated ears

"A type of abnormal location of the ears in which the position of the ears is characterized by posterior rotation (the superior part of the ears is rotated towards the back of the head, and the inferior part of the ears towards the front)." [HPO:probinson, pmid:19152421]

children.name: Synotia
children.defn: "A congenital malformation characterized by the union or approximation of the ears in front of the neck, often accompanied by the absence or defective development of the lower jaw." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Low-set ears
children.defn: "Upper insertion of the ear to the scalp below an imaginary horizontal line drawn between the inner canthi of the eye and extending posteriorly to the ear." [HPO:probinson, pmid:19152421]
"Abnormal location of the ear." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Extra concha fold
is_a_string: HP:0000356 ! Abnormality of the outer ear
children.defn: "Folds or ridges within the concha that are distinct from the crus helix." [eom:40563f1f62db2319, pmid:19152421]

children.name: Bilateral external ear deformity
is_a_string: HP:0000356 ! Abnormality of the outer ear

children.name: Abnormality of periauricular region
is_a_string: HP:0000356 ! Abnormality of the outer ear

children.name: Postauricular skin tag

children.name: Preauricular skin furrow

children.name: Pretragal ectopia

children.name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the external ear

children.defn: "A malformation of the auricle of the ear." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Cochlear degeneration

children.name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the cochlea
is_a_string: HP:0008774 ! Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the inner ear

children.name: Hypoplasia of the cochlea
children.defn: "Developmental hypoplasia of the cochlea." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Cochlear aplasia
children.defn: "Absence of the cochlea, a spiral shaped cavity in the inner ear, owing to a developmental defect." [HPO:dfitzpatrick]
"Absence or underdevelopment of the cochlea, a spiral shaped cavity in the inner ear, owing to a developmental defect." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Cochlear malformation
Incomplete partition of the cochlea
Incomplete partition of the cochlea type II
is_a_string: HP:0011373 ! Incomplete partition of the cochlea
children.defn: "The cochlea is lacking the entire modiolus and cribriform area, resulting in a cystic appearance. This is accompanied by a large cystic vestibule." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Incomplete partition of the cochlea type I
is_a_string: HP:0011373 ! Incomplete partition of the cochlea
children.defn: "The cochlea is lacking the entire modiolus and cribriform area, resulting in a cystic appearance. This is accompanied by a large cystic vestibule." [DDD:mbitner-glidicz]

"Incomplete formation of the cochlear partition. The scala vestibuli and scala tympani separated by the cochlear partition, except in the apical turn where the two scalae are in continuity via the helicotrema." [HPO:probinson]
"The presence of a malformed cochlea." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Enlarged cochlear aqueduct
children.defn: "Increased size of the cochlear duct, i.e., of a duct that communicates between the perilymphatic space and the subarachnoid space, and transmits a vein from the cochlea to join the internal jugular." [DDD:dfitzpatrick]
"An abnormality of the cochlea." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Morphological abnormality of the nerves of the inner ear

children.name: Dilatated internal auditory canal
is_a_string: HP:0011384 ! Abnormality of the internal auditory canal
children.defn: "The presence of a dilated inner part of external acoustic meatus." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Absent internal auditory canal
is_a_string: HP:0011384 ! Abnormality of the internal auditory canal

children.name: Narrow internal auditory canal
is_a_string: HP:0011384 ! Abnormality of the internal auditory canal
children.defn: "Reduction in diameter of the internal auditory canal." [DDD:dfitzpatrick]

"An abnormality of the Internal acoustic meatus, i.e., of the canal in the petrous part of the temporal bone through which the cranial nerve VII and cranial nerve VIII traverse." [DDD:mbitner-glidicz]

children.name: Morphological abnormality of the vestibule of the inner ear

children.defn: "Dilatation of the vestibule of the inner ear." [DDD:mbitner-glidicz]

is_a_string: HP:0011376 ! Morphological abnormality of the vestibule of the inner ear
children.defn: "Complete absence of the vestibule of the inner ear." [DDD:dfitzpatrick]

children.name: Hypoplasia of the vestibule of the inner ear
is_a_string: HP:0011376 ! Morphological abnormality of the vestibule of the inner ear
children.defn: "Underdevelopment of the vestibule of the inner ear." [DDD:mbitner-glidicz]

children.name: Morphological abnormality of the saccule
is_a_string: HP:0011380 ! Morphological abnormality of the semicircular canal

children.name: Enlarged semicircular canal
is_a_string: HP:0011380 ! Morphological abnormality of the semicircular canal
children.defn: "Increased size of the semicircular canal." [DDD:dfitzpatrick]

children.name: Hypoplasia of the semicircular canal
is_a_string: HP:0011380 ! Morphological abnormality of the semicircular canal
children.defn: "Underdevelopment of the semicircular canal." [DDD:dfitzpatrick]

children.name: Morphological abnormality of the posterior semicircular canal
is_a_string: HP:0011380 ! Morphological abnormality of the semicircular canal

children.name: Morphological abnormality of the lateral semicircular canal
is_a_string: HP:0011380 ! Morphological abnormality of the semicircular canal

children.name: Morphological abnormality of the utricle
is_a_string: HP:0011380 ! Morphological abnormality of the semicircular canal

children.name: Morphological abnormality of the anterior semicircular canal
is_a_string: HP:0011380 ! Morphological abnormality of the semicircular canal

children.defn: "An abnormality of the morphology of the semicircular canal." [DDD:dfitzpatrick]

children.name: Enlarged vestibular aqueduct
is_a_string: HP:0011376 ! Morphological abnormality of the vestibule of the inner ear
children.defn: "Increased size of the vestibular aqueduct." [DDD:mbitner-glidicz]

"A morphological abnormality of the vestibule, the central part of the osseous labyrinth that is situated medial to the tympanic cavity, behind the cochlea, and in front of the semicircular canals." [DDD:mbitner-glidicz]

children.name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the inner ear
is_a_string: HP:0011390 ! Morphological abnormality of the inner ear

children.name: Aplasia of the inner ear
is_a_string: HP:0008774 ! Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the inner ear
children.defn: "Absence of the inner ear due to a developmental defect." [DDD:dfitzpatrick]
"Aplasia or developmental hypoplasia of the inner ear." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Functional abnormality of the inner ear
is_a_string: HP:0000359 ! Abnormality of the inner ear

children.name: Vestibular dysfunction
is_a_string: HP:0011389 ! Functional abnormality of the inner ear

children.name: Vertigo
Paroxysmal vertigo
children.defn: "Paroxysmal episodes of vertigo." [HPO:curators]
"An abnormal sensation of spinning while the body is actually stationary." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Vestibular hypofunction
Absent vestibular function
children.defn: "Complete lack of functioning of the vestibular apparatus." [HPO:probinson]
"Reduced functioning of the vestibular apparatus." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Abnormal vestibulo-ocular reflex
Vestibular areflexia
children.defn: "Vestibular areflexia can be measured as the absence of the caloric nystagmus response in electronystagmography." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Impaired visually enhanced vestibulo-ocular reflex
children.defn: "The vestibulo-ocular reflex is responsible for the stabilization of the retinal image during movement. The visual vestibular ocular reflex (VVOR) or visual enhanced VOR, maintains ocular stability during head motion by generating compensatory eye movement opposite to head movement, and is a major component of visual vestibular\ninteraction. This feature is an impairment of this reflex, manifested as the combined impairment of the three compensatory eye movement reflexes, namely the vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR), smooth pursuit (SP) and optokinetic reflex (OKR)." [HPO:probinson, pmid:16954982]

"An abnormality of the vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR). The VOR attempts to keep the image stable on the retina. Ideally passive or active head movements in one direction are compensated for by eye movements of equal magnitude." [HPO:probinson, pmid:3625219]
"An abnormality of the functioning of the vestibular apparatus." [HPO:probinson]
"An abnormality of the function of the inner ear." [DDD:dfitzpatrick]
"An abnormality of the inner ear." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the ear
children.defn: "The presence of aplasia or developmental hypoplasia of the ear." [HPO:probinson]
"An abnormality of the ear." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Neoplasm
Neoplasm by histology
Fibrous tissue neoplasm
Histiocytoma
children.defn: "A neoplasm containing histiocytes." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Fibroma
Lung fibroma
children.defn: "The presence of a lung fibroma, a benign neoplasm that can present as a mass causing airway obstruction, cough, and hemoptysis, or present without symptoms as a solitary pulmonary nodule." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Fibroma of the breast
children.defn: "The presence of a fibroma of the breast." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Angiofibromas
children.defn: "Angiofibroma consist of many often dilated vessels." [HPO:curators]

"Benign tumors that are composed of fibrous or connective tissue. They can grow in all organs, arising from mesenchyme tissue. The term \"fibroblastic\" or \"fibromatous\" is used to describe tumors of the fibrous connective tissue. When the term fibroma is used without modifier, it is usually considered benign, with the term fibrosarcoma reserved for malignant tumors." [HPO:curators]
"Any neoplasm composed of fibrous tissue." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Melanoma
children.defn: "The presence of a melanoma, a malignant cancer originating from pigment producing melanocytes. Melanoma can originate from the skin or the pigmented layers of the eye (the uvea)." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Nervous tissue neoplasm
Neuroectodermal neoplasm
Neuroepithelial neoplasm
Glioma
is_a_string: HP:0100705 ! Abnormality of the glial cells
HP:0100836 ! Malignant neoplasm of the central nervous system

children.name: Astrocytoma
Subependymal giant-cell astrocytoma
children.defn: "A demarcated, largely intraventricular tumor in the region of the foramen of Monro composed of spindle to large plump or ganglion-like cells with eosinophilic to amphophilic cytoplasm and somewhat pleomorphic nuclei with occasional prominent nucleoli. These tumors are almost always associated with tuberous sclerosis." [HPO:curators]
"Astrocytoma is a neoplasm of the central nervous system derived from astrocytes. Astrocytes are a type of glial cell, and thus astrocytoma is a subtype of glioma." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Glioblastoma multiforme
children.defn: "A tumor arising from glia in the central nervous system with macroscopic regions of necrosis and hemorrhage. Microscopically, glioblastoma multiforme is characterized by regions of pseudopalisading necrosis, pleomorphic nuclei and cells, and microvascular proliferation." [HPO:probinson, pmid:10841526]

children.name: Optic glioma
children.defn: "A glioma originating in the optic nerve or optic chiasm." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Cerebellar glioma
children.defn: "A glioma affecting the cerebellum." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Brainstem glioma
children.defn: "A glioma affecting the brainstem." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Ependymoma
children.defn: "The presence of an ependymoma of the central nervous system." [HPO:probinson]
"The presence of a glioma, which is a neoplasm of the central nervous system originating from a glial cell (astrocytes or oligodendrocytes)." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Primitive neuroectodermal tumor
Central primitive neuroectodermal tumor
Medulloepithelioma
children.defn: "A primitive neuroectodermal tumor that originates from the cells of the embryonic medullary canal." [pmid:17566306]

children.name: Ependymoblastoma
children.defn: "A highly malignant embryonal tumor of infancy and young childhood characterized by neuroectodermal elements organized in distinctive multilayered rosettes. Ependymoblastomas are large lesions that occur in the supratentorial compartment, typically displaying a physical connection to the ventricular system. " []
"A primitive neuroectodermal neoplasm that occurs in the central nervous system." []

children.name: Peripheral primitive neuroectodermal neoplasm
Neuroblastoma
Olfactory esthesioneuroblastoma
children.defn: "A malignant olfactory neuroblastoma arising from the olfactory epithelium of the superior nasal cavity and cribriform plate." []

"Neuroblastoma is a solid tumor that originate in neural crest cells of the sympathetic nervous system. Most neuroblastomas originate in the abdomen, and most abdominal neuroblastomas originate in the adrenal gland. Neuroblastomas can also originate in the thorax, usually in the posterior mediastinum." [HPO:probinson]
"A primitive neuroectodermal neoplasm that occurs extracranially in soft tissue and bone." []

"A tumor that originates in cells from the primitive neural crest. This group of tumors is characteirzed by the presence of primitive cells with elements of neuronal and/or glial differentiation. " []

children.name: Neurocytoma
children.defn: "A benign brain tumor composed of neural elements which most often arise from the septum pellucidum and the walls of the lateral ventricles." []
"A neoplasm composed of neural epithelium, not necessarily a neoplasm located in the neural epithelium or neuroepithelium." []

children.name: Craniopharyngioma
children.defn: "A benign pituitary-region neoplasm that originates from Rathke's pouch. Craniopharyngiomas are benign slow growing tumours that are located within the sellar and para sellar region of the central nervous system." [pmid:17425791]
"A neoplasm arising in the neuroectoderm, the portion of the ectoderm of the early embryo that gives rise to the central and peripheral nervous systems, including some glial cells." []
"A neoplasm derived from nervous tissue (not necessarity a neoplasm located in the nervous system)." []

children.name: Hamartoma
Cerebral hamartomata
is_a_string: HP:0100835 ! Benign neoplasm of the central nervous system

children.name: Cortical tubers
is_a_string: HP:0002538 ! Abnormality of the cerebral cortex
children.defn: "Cortical tubers in the brain are hamartomatous lesions typically located at the gray-white matter interface, commonly in the frontal and parietal lobes. Cortical tubers are composed of abnormal glial and neural cells, and the size, number, and location vary among patients." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Subependymal nodules
is_a_string: HP:0002118 ! Abnormality of the cerebral ventricles
children.defn: "Small nodular masses which originate in the subependymal region of the lateral ventricles and protrude into the ventricular cavity. They may represent subependymal hamartomas of tuberous sclerosis or nodular heterotopia of grey matter." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Hypothalamic hamartoma
children.defn: "The presence of a hamartoma of the hypothalamus." [HPO:curators]
"The presence of a hamartoma of the cerebrum." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Chorangioma
children.defn: "Hamartoma-like growth in the placenta consisting of blood vessels." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Fibrous hamartoma
children.defn: "A rare, benign soft tissue tumor that typically occurs within the first two years of life." [HPO:sdoelken]

"A disordered proliferation of mature tissues that is native to the site of origin - eg, exostoses, nevi and soft tissue hamartomas. Although most hamartomas are benign, some histologic subtypes - eg, neuromuscular hamartoma, may proliferate aggressively such as mesenchymal cystic hamartoma, Sclerosing epithelial hamartoma, Sclerosing metanephric hamartoma." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Sarcoma
Neurofibrosarcoma
children.defn: "A form of malignant cancer of the connective tissue surrounding nerves. Given its origin and behavior, it is classified as a sarcoma." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Ewing's sarcoma
children.defn: "A malignant tumor of the bone which always arises in the medullary tissue, occurring more often in cylindrical bones." [HPO:probinson, pmid:17272319]

children.name: Synovial sarcoma
children.defn: "A type of mesenchymal tissue cell tumor that exhibits epithelial differentiation, which most frequently arises in the extremities." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Alveolar soft part sarcoma
children.defn: "A type of soft tissue sarcoma with a histological appearance reminiscent of alveoli because of  its reticulated fibrous stroma enclosing groups of sarcoma cells, which resemble epithelial cells and are enclosed in alveoli walled with connective tissue." [HPO:probinson, pmid:11244503]

children.name: Osteosarcoma
is_a_string: HP:0010622 ! Neoplasm of the skeletal system
children.defn: "A malignant bone tumor that usually develops during adolescence and usually affects the long bones including the tibia, femur, and humerus. The typical symptoms of osteosarcoma comprise bone pain, fracture, limitation of motion, and tenderness or swelling at the site of the tumor." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Chondrosarcoma
is_a_string: HP:0010622 ! Neoplasm of the skeletal system
children.defn: "A slowly growing malignant neoplasm derived from cartilage cells." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Fibrosarcoma
children.defn: "A fibroblastic sarcoma is a malignant tumor derived from fibrous connective tissue and characterized by immature proliferating fibroblasts or undifferentiated anaplastic spindle cells." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Leiomyosarcoma
children.defn: "A smooth muscle connective tissue tumor, which is rare type of cancer that is a malignant neoplasm of smooth muscle. When such a neoplasm is benign, it is called a leiomyoma." [HPO:sdoelken]
"The presence of a sarcoma." [HPO:sdoelken]
"Neoplasm categorized according to type of histological abnormality." [DDD:rscott]

children.name: Neoplasm by anatomical site
Neoplasm of the respiratory system
is_a_string: HP:0002086 ! Abnormality of the respiratory system

children.name: Neoplasm of the larynx
is_a_string: HP:0100606 ! Neoplasm of the respiratory system

children.name: Laryngeal carcinoma
children.defn: "A carcinoma of the larynx." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Neoplasm of the lung
is_a_string: HP:0100606 ! Neoplasm of the respiratory system

children.name: Pulmonary lymphoma
children.defn: "Lung parenchymal involvement with lymphoma." [DDD:tkuijpers]

children.name: Bronchial neoplasm
children.defn: "A tumor originating in a bronchus." []

children.name: Neoplasm of the tracheobronchial system
is_a_string: HP:0005607 ! Abnormality of the tracheobronchial system

children.name: Pleuropulmonary blastoma
is_a_string: HP:0100552 ! Neoplasm of the tracheobronchial system
children.defn: "A rare cancer originating in the lung or pleural cavity that occurs most often in infants and young children but also has been reported in adults. Pleuropulmonary blastoma is regarded as malignant." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Alveolar cell carcinoma
is_a_string: HP:0100552 ! Neoplasm of the tracheobronchial system
children.defn: "Adenocarcinoma of the Bronchus." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Neoplasm of the trachea
is_a_string: HP:0100552 ! Neoplasm of the tracheobronchial system
children.defn: "A neoplasm of the trachea." []
"Tumor of the lung." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Neoplasia of the pleura
is_a_string: HP:0100606 ! Neoplasm of the respiratory system

children.name: Pleural mesothelioma
children.defn: "A Malignant mesothelioma originating from cells of the pleura (the thin layer of mesothelium lining the lungs). Pleural mesothelioma is the most common form of mesothelioma." [HPO:sdoelken]
"A benign or malignant neoplasm (tumour) originating in the respiratory system." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Hematological neoplasm
is_a_string: HP:0001871 ! Abnormality of blood and blood-forming tissues

children.name: Myelodysplasia
Single lineage myelodysplasia
Refractory anemia with ringed sideroblasts
children.defn: "A type of myelodysplastic syndrome characterized by less than 5% myeloblasts in the bone marrow, but with 15% or greater red cell precursors in the marrow being abnormal iron-stuffed cells called ringed sideroblasts." [HPO:probinson]
"Abnormality/dysplasia of a single myeloid cell (erythroid, granulocytic, or megakaryocytic)." [DDD:akelly]

children.name: Bilineage myelodysplasia
children.defn: "Myelodysplasia with dysplastic changes in two of the myeloid lineages: erythroid, granulocytic, megakaryocytic." [DDD:akelly]

children.name: Multiple lineage myelodysplasia
children.defn: "Myelodysplasia with dysplastic changes in two or more of the myeloid lineages: erythroid, granulocytic, megakaryocytic." [DDD:akelly]
"Clonal hematopoietic stem cell disorders characterized by dysplasia (ineffective production) in one or more hematopoietic cell lineages, leading to anemia and cytopenia." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Multiple myeloma
children.defn: "A malignant plasma cell tumor growing within soft tissue or within the skeleton." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Plasmacytoma
children.defn: "A discrete mass of neoplastic monoclonal plasma cells either in the bone marrow or in an extramedullary location." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Lymphoma
Hodgkin lymphoma
children.defn: "A typer of lymphoma characterized microscopically by multinucleated Reed-Sternberg cells." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Non-Hodgkin lymphoma
Primary central nervous system lymphoma
children.defn: "A form of extranodal, high-grade non-Hodgkin B-cell neoplasm, usually large cell or immunoblastic type that originates in the brain, leptomeninges, spinal cord, or eyes and typically remains confined to the CNS. " [pmid:23696924]

children.name: Burkitt lymphoma
children.defn: "A form of undifferentiated malignant lymphoma commonly manifested as a large osteolytic lesion in the jaw or as an abdominal mass." []

children.name: T-cell lymphoma
T-cell lymphoma/leukemia
children.defn: "A type of T-cell lymphoma in which cancerous T-cells may present in the blood (leukemia), lymph nodes (lymphoma), skin or in multiple areas." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Anaplastic large-cell lymphoma
children.defn: "A type of T-cell lymphoma that is characterized by so-called hallmark cells with a pleomorphic appearance that express the CD30 antigen, are lobulated, and have indented nuclei. These so-called hallmark cells have lobulated and indented nuclei." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma
children.defn: "A type of T-cell lymphoma that exhibits malignant infiltration of the skin." [HPO:probinson]
"A type of lymphoma that originates in T-cells." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: B-cell lymphoma
children.defn: "A type of lymphoma that originates in B-cells." [HPO:probinson]
"A typer of lymphoma characterized microscopically by the absence of multinucleated Reed-Sternberg cells." [HPO:probinson]
"A cancer originating in lymphocytes and presenting as a solid tumor of lymhpoid cells." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Malignant mesothelioma
children.defn: "Malignant mesothelioma is a form of cancer that originates from the cells of the mesothelium, a thin tissue layer surrounding the body's internal organs. Malignant mesothelioma is almost exclusively caused by asbestos exposure, pleural mesothelioma beeing the most common form, affecting the lining of the lungs called the pleura. Other forms such as perioneal-, percardial- or testicular- mesothelioma are much rarer." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Neoplasm of the skeletal system
Osteoblastoma
is_a_string: HP:0010622 ! Neoplasm of the skeletal system
children.defn: "A benign, painful, tumor of bone characterized by the formation of osteoid tissue, primitive bone and calcified tissue." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Enchondroma
is_a_string: HP:0010622 ! Neoplasm of the skeletal system
children.defn: "A solitary, benign, intramedullary cartilage tumor that is often found in the short tubular bones of the hands and feet, distal femur, and proximal humerus. " []

children.name: Giant cell tumor of bone
is_a_string: HP:0010622 ! Neoplasm of the skeletal system
children.defn: "A bone tumor composed of cellular spindle-cell stroma containing scattered multinucleated giant cells resembling osteoclasts." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Chordoma
is_a_string: HP:0010622 ! Neoplasm of the skeletal system
children.defn: "A chordoma is a tumors that arises from embryonic remnants of the notochord along the length of the neuraxis. Chordomas generally occur in the sacrum, intracranially at the clivus, or along the spinal axis." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Exostoses
is_a_string: HP:0010622 ! Neoplasm of the skeletal system

children.name: Rib exostoses
children.defn: "Multiple circumscribed bony excrescences located in the ribs." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Scapular exostoses
children.defn: "The presence of multiple exostoses on the scapula. An exostosis is a benign growth the projects outward from the bone surface. It is cappped by cartilage." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Multiple exostoses
Multiple digital exostoses
children.defn: "Multiple exostoses originating in the fingers and toes." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Multiple long-bone exostoses
children.defn: "Multiple exostoses originating in long bones." [HPO:probinson]

"Presence of more than one exostosis. An exostosis is a benign growth the projects outward from the bone surface. It is cappped by cartilage, and arises from a bone that develops from cartilage." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Pelvic exostoses
is_a_string: HP:0002644 ! Abnormality of pelvic girdle bone morphology
children.defn: "A benign growth the projects outward from the bone surface of the pelvis. Exostoses are cappped by cartilage, and arise from a bone that develops from cartilage." [HPO:probinson]
"An exostosis is a benign growth the projects outward from the bone surface. It is cappped by cartilage, and arises from a bone that develops from cartilage." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Osteoma
is_a_string: HP:0010622 ! Neoplasm of the skeletal system
children.defn: "Osteomas are bony growths found most commonly on the skull and mandible; however, they may occur in any bone of the body. Osteomas do not usually cause clinical problems and do not become malignant." [HPO:sdoelken]
"A benign or malignant neoplasm (tumour) originating in the skeleton." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Neoplasm of the nervous system
is_a_string: HP:0012639 ! Abnormality of nervous system morphology

children.name: Neoplasm of the central nervous system
is_a_string: HP:0002011 ! Morphological abnormality of the central nervous system
HP:0004375 ! Neoplasm of the nervous system

children.name: Benign neoplasm of the central nervous system
is_a_string: HP:0100006 ! Neoplasm of the central nervous system

children.name: Meningioma
is_a_string: HP:0100835 ! Benign neoplasm of the central nervous system
children.defn: "The presence of a meningioma, i.e., a benign tumor originating from the dura mater or arachnoid mater." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Hemangioblastoma
is_a_string: HP:0100835 ! Benign neoplasm of the central nervous system

children.name: Cerebellar hemangioblastoma
children.defn: "A 'hemangioblastoma of the cerebellum." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Spinal hemangioblastoma
children.defn: "A 'hemangioblastoma of the spinal cord." [HPO:curators]

"A hemangioblastoma is a benign vascular neoplasm that arises almost exclusively in the central nervous system. Hemangioblastomas consist of a tightly packed cluster of small blood vessels forming a mass of up to 1 or 2 cm in diameter." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Choroid plexus papilloma
is_a_string: HP:0007376 ! Abnormality of the choroid plexus
HP:0100835 ! Benign neoplasm of the central nervous system
children.defn: "Choroid plexus papilloma is a histologically benign neoplasm located in the ventricular system of the choroid plexus." [HPO:skoehler]

children.name: Malignant neoplasm of the central nervous system
is_a_string: HP:0100006 ! Neoplasm of the central nervous system

children.name: Neuroblastic tumors
is_a_string: HP:0100836 ! Malignant neoplasm of the central nervous system

children.name: Ganglioneuroma
children.defn: "A benign neoplasm that usually arises from the sympathetic trunk in the mediastinum, representing a tumor of the sympathetic nerve fibers arising from neural crest cells." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Medulloblastoma
is_a_string: HP:0100836 ! Malignant neoplasm of the central nervous system
children.defn: "A rapidly growing embryonic tumor arising in the posterior part of the cerebellar vermis and neuroepithelial roof of the fourth ventricle in children. More rarely, medulloblastoma arises in the cerebellum in adults." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Spinal cord tumor
is_a_string: HP:0002143 ! Abnormality of the spinal cord
HP:0100006 ! Neoplasm of the central nervous system
children.defn: "A neoplasm affecting the spinal cord." [HPO:probinson]
"A neoplasm of the central nervous system." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Neoplasm of the peripheral nervous system
is_a_string: HP:0000759 ! Abnormal peripheral nervous system morphology
HP:0004375 ! Neoplasm of the nervous system

children.name: Peripheral neuroepithelioma
is_a_string: HP:0100007 ! Neoplasm of the peripheral nervous system

children.name: Schwannoma
is_a_string: HP:0100007 ! Neoplasm of the peripheral nervous system
children.defn: "A benign nerve sheath tumor composed of Schwann cells." [HPO:sdoelken]
"A benign or malignant neoplasm (tumour) of the peripheral nervous system." [HPO:probinson]
"A neoplasm affecting the nervous system." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Neoplasm of head and neck
Mouth neoplasm
is_a_string: HP:0012288 ! Neoplasm of head and neck
children.defn: "A neoplasm of the mouth." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Facial neoplasm
is_a_string: HP:0012288 ! Neoplasm of head and neck
children.defn: "A neoplasm of the face." [HPO:probinson]
"A neoplasm of the head and neck region with origin in the lip, oral cavity, nasal cavity, paranasal sinuses, pharynx, and larynx." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Neoplasm of the breast
Breast carcinoma
Multifocal breast carcinoma
children.defn: "Breast carcinoma that is bilateral or otherwise multifocal." [HPO:probinson]
"The presence of a carcinoma of the breast." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Ductal carcinoma in situ
children.defn: "Presence of abnormal cells inside a milk duct, that is, non-invasive breast cancer. Ductal carcinoma in situ is considered to be a precursor lesion to invasive breast cancer." [pmid:24415964]
"A neoplasm of the breast." [HPO:probinson]
"Neoplasm categorized according to the anatomical site of origin of the neoplasm." [DDD:rscott]
"An organ or organ-system abnormality that consists of uncontrolled autonomous cell-proliferation which can occur in any part of the body as a benign or malignant neoplasm (tumour)." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Growth delay
Postnatal growth retardation
Mild postnatal growth retardation
children.defn: "A mild degree of slow or limited growth after birth, being between two and three standard deviations below age- and sex-related norms." [DDD:hfirth]

children.name: Moderate postnatal growth retardation
children.defn: "A moderate degree of slow or limited growth after birth, being between three and four standard deviations below age- and sex-related norms." [DDD:hfirth]

children.name: Severe postnatal growth retardation
children.defn: "Severely slow or limited growth after birth, being four standard deviations or more below age- and sex-related norms." [DDD:hfirth]
"Slow or limited growth after birth." [DDD:hfirth]

children.name: Intrauterine growth retardation
Moderate intrauterine growth retardation
children.defn: "Intrauterine growth retardation that is at least 3 standard deviations (SD) below average, but not as low as 4 SD, corrected for sex and gestational age." [DDD:hfirth]

children.name: Mild intrauterine growth retardation
children.defn: "Intrauterine growth retardation that is at least 2 standard deviations (SD) below average, but not as low as 3 SD, corrected for sex and gestational age." [DDD:hfirth]

children.name: Severe intrauterine growth retardation
children.defn: "Intrauterine growth retardation that is 4 or more standard deviations below average, corrected for sex and gestational age." [HPO:probinson]
"An abnormal restriction of fetal growth with fetal weight below the tenth percentile for gestational age." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Short stature
Disproportionate short stature
Disproportionate short-trunk short stature
Lethal short-trunk short stature
children.defn: "A type of disproportionate short stature characterized by a short trunk but a average-sized limbs that is lethal at birth." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Infancy onset short-trunk short stature
children.defn: "A type of disproportionate short stature characterized by a short trunk but a average-sized limbs with onset in infancy." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Neonatal short-trunk short stature
children.defn: "A type of disproportionate short stature characterized by a short trunk but a average-sized limbs with congenital onset recognizable at birth." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Childhood-onset short-trunk short stature
children.defn: "A type of disproportionate short stature characterized by a short trunk but a average-sized limbs with onset in childhood." [HPO:probinson]
"A type of disproportionate short stature characterized by a short trunk but a average-sized limbs." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Disproportionate short-limb short stature
Mesomelic short stature
children.defn: "A type of disproportionate short stature characterized by disproportionate shortening of the medial parts of the extremities (forearm or lower leg)." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Neonatal short-limb short stature
children.defn: "A type of short-limbed dwarfism that is manifest beginning in the neonatal period." [HPO:probinson]
"A type of disproportionate short stature characterized by a short limbs but an average-sized trunk." [HPO:probinson]
"A kind of short stature in which different regions of the body are shortened to differing extents." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Proportionate short stature
Severe short stature
children.defn: "A severe degree of short stature, more than -4 SD from the mean corrected for age and sex." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Moderately short stature
children.defn: "A moderate degree of short stature, more than -3 SD but not more than -4 SD from mean corrected for age and sex." [DDD:hfirth]

children.name: Mild short stature
children.defn: "A mild degree of short stature, more than -2 SD but not more than -3 SD from mean corrected for age and sex." [DDD:hfirth]
"A kind of short stature in which different regions of the body are shortened to a comparable extent." [HPO:probinson]

"A height below that which is expected according to age and gender norms. Although there is no universally accepted definition of short stature, many refer to \"short stature\" as height more than 2 standard deviations below the mean for age and gender (or below the 3rd percentile for age and gender dependent norms)." [HPO:curators]
"A deficiency or slowing down of growth pre- and postnatally." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Abnormality of body height
Tall stature
Disproportionate tall stature
children.defn: "A tall and slim body build with increased arm span to height ratio (>1.05) and a reduced upper-to-lower segment ratio (<0.85), i.e., unusually long arms and legs. The extremities as well as the hands and feet are unusually slim." [DDD:hfirth, HPO:probinson]

children.name: Slender build
children.defn: "Asthenic habitus refers to a slender build with long limbs, an angular profile, and prominent muscles or bones." [HPO:probinson]
"A height above that which is expected according to age and gender norms." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Abnormal upper to lower segment ratio
Reduced upper to lower segment ratio
is_a_string: HP:0012772 ! Abnormal upper to lower segment ratio
children.defn: "Decreased ratio between the upper and the lower segment of the body, where the lower segment is defined as the length between the top of pubic symphysis to floor, and the upper segment is defined as the top of head to top of pubic symphysis." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Increased upper to lower segment ratio
is_a_string: HP:0012772 ! Abnormal upper to lower segment ratio
children.defn: "Elevated ratio between the upper and the lower segment of the body, where the lower segment is defined as the length between the top of pubic symphysis to floor, and the upper segment is defined as the top of head to top of pubic symphysis." [HPO:probinson]

"A deviation from normal of the relation between the upper and the lower segment of the body, where the lower segment is defined as the length between the top of pubic symphysis to floor, and the upper segment is defined as the top of head to top of pubic symphysis." [HPO:probinson]
"Deviation from the norm of height with respect to that which is expected according to age and gender norms." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Asymmetric growth
children.defn: "A growth pattern that displays an abnormal difference between the left and the right side." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Abnormality of body weight
Obesity
Abdominal obesity
children.defn: "Excessive fat around the stomach and abdomen." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Truncal obesity
Childhood-onset truncal obesity
children.defn: "Truncal obesity with onset during childhood, defined as between 2 and 10 years of age." [HPO:probinson]
"Obesity located preferentially in the trunk of the body as opposed to the extremities." [HPO:probinson]

"Body weight that is grossly above the acceptable or desirable weight, usually due to accumulation of excess fats in the body. The standards may vary with age, sex, genetic or cultural background. In the body mass index (BMI), a BMI greater than 30.0 kg/m2 is considered obese, and a BMI greater than 40.0 kg/m2 is considered morbidly obese." [HPO:probinson, MeSH:D009765]

children.name: Large for gestational age
children.defn: "The term large for gestational age applies to babies whose birth weight lies above the 90th percentile for that gestational age." [eMedicine:262679, HPO:probinson]

children.name: Small for gestational age
children.defn: "Smaller than normal size according to sex and gestational age related norms, defined as a weight below the 10th percentile for the gestational age." [DDD:hfirth]

children.name: Weight loss
Cachexia
children.defn: "Severe weight loss, wasting of muscle, loss of appetite, and general debility related to a chronic disease." [HPO:probinson]
"Reduction inexisting body weight." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Failure to thrive
children.defn: "Failure to thrive (FTT) refers to a child whose physical growth is substantially below the norm." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Eunuchoid habitus
children.defn: "A body habitus that is tall, slim and underweight, with long legs and long arms (i.e., arm span exceeds height by 5 cm or more)." [HPO:probinson]
"An abnormal increase or decrease of weight or an abnormal distribution of mass in the body." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Prenatal movement abnormality
is_a_string: HP:0001197 ! Abnormality of prenatal development or birth

children.name: Decreased fetal movement
Fetal akinesia sequence
children.defn: "Decreases fetal activity associated with multiple joint contractures, facial anomalies and pulmonary hypoplasia. Ultrasound examination may reveal polyhydramnios, ankylosis, scalp edema, and decreased chest movements (reflecting pulmonary hypoplasia)." [HPO:probinson]
"An abnormal reduction in quantity or strength of fetal movements." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Increased fetal movement
children.defn: "An abnormal increase in quantity or strength of fetal movements." [HPO:curators]
"An abnormality of fetal movement." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Premature birth
is_a_string: HP:0001197 ! Abnormality of prenatal development or birth

children.name: Premature delivery because of cervical insufficiency or membrane fragility

children.defn: "The birth of a baby of less than 37 weeks of gestational age." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Fetal ultrasound soft marker
is_a_string: HP:0001197 ! Abnormality of prenatal development or birth

children.name: Short fetal humerus length
children.defn: "A short humerus length is defined as a length below the 2.5th percentile for gestational age or as a measurement less than 0.9 of that predicted by the measured biparietal diameter. The humerus should be measured with the bone perpendicular to the ultrasound beam and with epiphyseal cartilages visible but not included in the measurement (pmid:16100637)." [HPO:probinson, pmid:16100637]

children.name: Echogenic fetal bowel
children.defn: "Echogenic bowel is defined as fetal bowel with homogenous areas of echogenicity that are equal to or greater than that of surrounding bone." [HPO:probinson, pmid:16100637, pmid:20175047]

children.name: Short fetal femur length
children.defn: "A short femur length is defined as either a measurement below the 2.5th percentile for gestational age or a measurement that is less than 0.9 of that predicted by the measured biparietal diameter. The femur should be measured with the bone perpendicular to the ultrasound beam and with epiphyseal cartilages visible but not included in the measurement (pmid:16100637)." [HPO:probinson, pmid:16100637]

children.name: Mild fetal ventriculomegaly
children.defn: "A kind of ventriculomegaly occurring in the fetal period and usually diagnosed by prenatal ultrasound. Cerebral ventriculomegaly is defined by atrial measurements 10 mm or more. Mild ventriculomegaly (MVM) is defined as measurements between 10 and 15 mm. Measurements are obtained from an axial plane at the level of the thalamic nuclei just below the standard image to measure the BPD (pmid:16100637)." [HPO:probinson, pmid:16100637]

children.name: Fetal choroid plexus cysts
children.defn: "Fetal choroid plexus cysts (CPCs) are sonographically discrete, small cysts (3 mm or more) found in the choroid plexus within the lateral cerebral ventricles of the developing fetus at 14 to 24 weeks gestation. Imaging of the choroid plexus is performed in the transverse plane of the fetal head at the same level that the lateral cerebral ventricle is evaluated. The choroid plexus should be inspected bilaterally for the presence of cysts. The size of CPCs is not of clinical relevance (pmid:16100637)." [DDD:hfirth, pmid:16100637]

children.name: Enlarged fetal cisterna magna
children.defn: "The cisterna magna is measured on a transaxial view of the fetal head angled 15 degrees caudal to the canthomeatal line. The anterior/posterior diameter is taken between the inferior/posterior surface of the vemis of the cerebellum to the inner surface of the cranium. An enlarged cisternal magna is defined by an anterior/posterior diameter of 10 mm or more (pmid:16100637)." [DDD:hfirth, pmid:16100637]

children.name: Fetal fifth finger clinodactyly
children.defn: "Fifth finger clinodactyly is defined by a hypoplastic or absent mid-phalanx of the fifth digit. Ultrasound identification of the fetal hand must first be undertaken and then appropriate magnification accomplished. The evaluation requires stretching of the 5 fingers. The diagnosis is established when the middle phalanx of the fifth finger is markedly smaller than normal or absent, which often causes the finger to be curved inward  (pmid:16100637)." [HPO:probinson, pmid:16100637]

children.name: Hypoplasia of fetal nasal bone
children.defn: "On prenatal ultrasound, the nasal bone is a thin echogenic line within the bridge of the fetal nose. The fetus is imaged facing the transducer with the fetal face strictly in the midline. The angle of insonation is 90 degrees, with the longitudinal axis of the nasal bone as the reference line. Calibres are placed at each end of the nasal bone. Absence of the nasal bone or measurements below 2.5th percentile are considered significant (pmid:16100637)." [HPO:probinson, pmid:16100637]

children.name: Absence of stomach bubble on fetal sonography
children.defn: "By the 14th week of gestation it is nearly always possible to visualized the fluid-filled fetal stomach bubble on prenatal sonography. This term refers to the absence of a normal fetal stomach bubble on fetal ultrasonography performed at around 16 to 20 weeks' gestation." [HPO:probinson]

"An finding upon obstetric ultrasound examination performed at around 16 to 20 weeks of gestation that is abnormal but not clearly identifiable as a  fetal anatomic malformation or growth restriction. Such findings are known as soft markers since they are associated with increased risk for fetal aneuploidy or other disorders." [pmid:16100637]

children.name: Abnormality of the amniotic fluid
is_a_string: HP:0001197 ! Abnormality of prenatal development or birth

children.name: Polyhydramnios
is_a_string: HP:0001560 ! Abnormality of the amniotic fluid
children.defn: "The presence of excess amniotic fluid in the uterus during pregnancy." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Oligohydramnios
is_a_string: HP:0001560 ! Abnormality of the amniotic fluid
children.defn: "Diminished amniotic fluid volume in pregnancy." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Fetal polyuria
is_a_string: HP:0001560 ! Abnormality of the amniotic fluid
children.defn: "Abnormally increased production of urine by the fetus resulting in polyhydramnios." [HPO:probinson, pmid:21460147]

children.name: Meconium stained amniotic fluid
is_a_string: HP:0001560 ! Abnormality of the amniotic fluid
children.defn: "Amniotic fluid containing the earliest stools of a mammalian infant." [HPO:probinson]
"Abnormality of the amniotic fluid, which is the fluid contained in the amniotic sac surrounding the developing fetus." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Abnormalities of placenta or umbilical cord
is_a_string: HP:0001197 ! Abnormality of prenatal development or birth

children.name: Abnormality of placental membranes
is_a_string: HP:0001194 ! Abnormalities of placenta or umbilical cord

children.name: Amniotic constriction ring
Digital constriction ring
children.defn: "A narrow segment of significantly reduced circumference of a digit." [pmid:19125433]

"Annular constrictions around the digits, limbs, or trunk, occurring congenitally (sometimes causing intrauterine autoamputation) and also associated with a wide variety of disorders. Constrictive amniotic bands are the result of primary amniotic rupture, which can lead to entanglement of fetal tissue (especially limbs) in fibrous amniotic strands." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Abnormality of the umbilical cord
is_a_string: HP:0001194 ! Abnormalities of placenta or umbilical cord

children.name: Abnormal umbilical cord blood vessels
is_a_string: HP:0010881 ! Abnormality of the umbilical cord

children.name: Short umbilical cord
is_a_string: HP:0010881 ! Abnormality of the umbilical cord
children.defn: "Decreased length of the umbilical cord." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Long umbilical cord
is_a_string: HP:0010881 ! Abnormality of the umbilical cord
children.defn: "Increased length of the umbilical cord." [DDD:hfirth]

children.name: Abnormal insertion of umbilical cord
is_a_string: HP:0010881 ! Abnormality of the umbilical cord

children.defn: "An abnormality of the umbilical cord, which is the cord connecting the developing embryo or fetus to the placenta." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Abnormality of the placenta
is_a_string: HP:0001194 ! Abnormalities of placenta or umbilical cord

children.name: Abnormal placental size
Small placenta
children.defn: "Reduced size of the placenta." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Large placenta
Hydropic placenta
children.defn: "An abnormality of the placenta in which there are numerous cystic spaces within the placenta as well as placental enlargement." [HPO:hfirth]
"Increased size of the placenta." [HPO:probinson]
"A deviation from normal size of the placenta." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Placental abruption
children.defn: "Separation of the placenta from the uterus wall before delivery." [DDD:hfirth]
"An abnormality of the placenta, the organ that connects the developing fetus to the uterine wall to enable nutrient uptake, waste elimination, and gas exchange." [HPO:probinson]
"An abnormality of the placenta (the organ that connects the developing fetus to the uterine wall) or of the umbilical cord (the cord that connects the fetus to the placenta)." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Prenatal maternal abnormality
