children.name: Dysmorphic inferior cerebellar vermis
is_a_string: HP:0002334 ! Abnormality of the cerebellar vermis
children.defn: "A structural anomaly of the inferior portion of the vermis of cerebellum." [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]
"An anomaly of the vermis of cerebellum." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the cerebellum
is_a_string: HP:0002977 ! Aplasia/Hypoplasia involving the central nervous system

children.name: Cerebellar agenesis
children.defn: "Lack of development of the cerebellum." [HPO:probinson, pmid:20305277]

children.name: Cerebellar hypoplasia
children.defn: "Underdevelopment of the cerebellum." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Abnormality of the dentate nucleus
Atrophy of the dentate nucleus
is_a_string: HP:0100321 ! Abnormality of the dentate nucleus

children.defn: "An abnormality of the dentate nucleus." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Cerebellar dysplasia
children.defn: "The presence of developmental dysplasia of the cerebellum." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Enlarged cerebellum
children.defn: "An abnormally increased size of the cerebellum compared to other brain structures." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Cerebellar gliosis
children.defn: "The presence of gliosis in the cerebellum." [UToronto:htrang]

children.name: Olivopontocerebellar atrophy
children.defn: "Neuronal degeneration in the cerebellum, pontine nuclei, and inferior olivary nucleus." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Ataxia
Cerebellar ataxia associated with quadrupedal gait
children.defn: "The presence of cerebellar signs and symptoms such as lack of balance associated with quadrupedal gait (locomotion on all four extremities with a 'bear-like' gait with the legs held straight)." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Dyssynergia
Asynergia
children.defn: "A type of dyssynergy characterized by the lack of the ability to smoothly perform the elements of a voluntary movement in the appropriate order and speed." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Ocular dyssynergia
children.defn: "A type of dyssynergia affecting eye movements and characterized by the inability to smoothly follow a visual target across the visual field." [HPO:probinson]

"A type of ataxia characterized by the impairment of the ability to smoothly perform the elements of a voluntary movement in the appropriate order and speed. With dyssynergia, a voluntary movement appears broken down into its component parts." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Dysmetria
Limb dysmetria
children.defn: "A type of dysmetria involving the limbs." [HPO:probinson]

"A type of ataxia characterized by the inability to carry out movements with the correct range and motion across the plane of more than one joint related to incorrect estimation of the distances required for targeted movements." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Intermittent cerebellar ataxia
children.defn: "Episodes or attacks of ataxia typically lasting from 10 minutes to several hours." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Truncal ataxia
children.defn: "Truncal ataxia is a sign of ataxia characterized by instability of the trunk. It usually occurs during sitting." [HPO:probinson, UKT:rschuele]

children.name: Dysdiadochokinesis
children.defn: "A type of ataxia characterized by the impairment of the ability to perform rapidly alternating movements, such as rhythmically tapping the fingers on the knee." [HPO:probinson, UKB:tklockgether]

children.name: Limb ataxia
children.defn: "A kind of ataxia that affects movements of the extremities." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Episodic ataxia
children.defn: "Periodic spells of incoordination and imbalance, that is, episodes of ataxia typically lasting from 10 minutes to several hours or days.\n" [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Gait ataxia
Progressive gait ataxia
children.defn: "A type of gait ataxia displaying progression of clinical severity." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Abasia
children.defn: "Ay severe form of gait ataxia such that an affected person cannot walk at all." [HPO:probinson]

"A type of ataxia characterized by the impairment of the ability to coordinate the movements required for normal walking. Gait ataxia is characteirzed by a wide-based staggering gait with a tendency to fall." [HPO:probinson, UKT:rschuele]

"Cerebellar ataxia refers to ataxia due to dysfunction of the cerebellum. This causes a variety of elementary neurological deficits including asynergy (lack of coordination between muscles, limbs and joints), dysmetria (lack of ability to judge distances that can lead to under- oder overshoot in grasping movements), and dysdiadochokinesia (inability to perform rapid movements requiring antagonizing muscle groups to be switched on and off repeatedly)." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Cerebellar atrophy
Spinocerebellar atrophy
children.defn: "Atrophy affecting the cerebellum and the spinocerebellar tracts of the spinal cord." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Cerebellar Purkinje layer atrophy
children.defn: "Atrophy of the cerebellum affecting primarily the Purkinje cell layer." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Cerebellar granular layer atrophy
children.defn: "Atrophy of the cerebellum affecting primarily the granular cell layer." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Pontocerebellar atrophy
children.defn: "Atrophy affecting the pons and the cerebellum." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Diffuse cerebellar atrophy
children.defn: "Diffuse unlocalised atrophy affecting the cerebellum." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Cerebellar cortical atrophy
children.defn: "Atrophy (wasting) of the cerebellar cortex." [HPO:probinson]
"Atrophy (wasting) of the cerebellum." [HPO:probinson, pmid:12169461]
"An abnormality of the cerebellum." [HPO:probinson]
"An abnormality of the metencephalon. The metencephalon is the part of the hindbrain that consists of the pons and the cerebellum." [HPO:probinson]
"An abnormality of the hindbrain, also known as the rhombencephalon." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Iron accumulation in brain
children.defn: "An abnormal build up of iron (Fe) in brain tissue." [HPO:probinson]
"A structural abnormality of the brain, which has as its parts the forebrain, midbrain, and hindbrain." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Abnormality of the glial cells
is_a_string: HP:0002011 ! Morphological abnormality of the central nervous system

children.name: Abnormality of the microglia
is_a_string: HP:0100705 ! Abnormality of the glial cells
children.defn: "An abnormality of the microglial cells. They are also known as brain-resident macrophages or hortega cells." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Abnormality of the oligodendroglia
is_a_string: HP:0100705 ! Abnormality of the glial cells
children.defn: "One of the three types of glia cells that, with the nerve cells, compose the central nervous system and are characterized by sheetlike processes that wrap around individual axons to form the myelin sheath of nerve fibers." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Gliosis
is_a_string: HP:0100705 ! Abnormality of the glial cells

children.name: Myelin-dependent gliosis
children.defn: "A type of gliosis that occurs in the vicinity of injured neurons." [HPO:probinson]
"The presence of gliosis in the central nervous system." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Astrocytosis
is_a_string: HP:0100705 ! Abnormality of the glial cells
children.defn: "Proliferation of astrocytes in the area of a lesion of the central nervous system." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Abnormality of the astrocytes
is_a_string: HP:0100705 ! Abnormality of the glial cells
children.defn: "An abnormality of astrocytes." [HPO:probinson]
"An abnormality of the glia cell." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Alzheimer disease
is_a_string: HP:0002011 ! Morphological abnormality of the central nervous system
children.defn: "A degenerative disease of the brain characterized by the insidious onset of dementia. Impairment of memory, judgment, attention span, and problem solving skills are followed by severe apraxia and a global loss of cognitive abilities. The condition primarily occurs after age 60, and is marked pathologically by severe cortical atrophy and the triad of senile plaques, neurofibrillary tangles, and neuropil threads." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Atrophy/Degeneration affecting the central nervous system
is_a_string: HP:0002011 ! Morphological abnormality of the central nervous system

children.name: Central nervous system degeneration
is_a_string: HP:0007367 ! Atrophy/Degeneration affecting the central nervous system

children.name: Neurodegeneration
is_a_string: HP:0007367 ! Atrophy/Degeneration affecting the central nervous system
children.defn: "Progressive loss of neural cells and tissue." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Increased cerebral lipofuscin
is_a_string: HP:0007367 ! Atrophy/Degeneration affecting the central nervous system

children.name: Increased extraneuronal autofluorescent lipopigment
children.defn: "Lipofuscin, a generic term applied to autofluorescent lipopigment, is a mixture of protein and lipid that accumulates in most aging cells, particularly those involved in high lipid turnover (e.g., the adrenal medulla) or phagocytosis of other cell types (e g., the retinal pigment epithelium or RPE; macrophage). This term pertains if there is an increase in the extraneuronal accumulation of lipofuscin (also known as autofluorescent lipoprotein) more than expected for the age of the patient." [HPO:probinson, pmid:11406682]

children.name: Increased neuronal autofluorescent lipopigment
children.defn: "Lipofuscin, a generic term applied to autofluorescent lipopigment, is a mixture of protein and lipid that accumulates in most aging cells, particularly those involved in high lipid turnover (e.g., the adrenal medulla) or phagocytosis of other cell types (e g., the retinal pigment epithelium or RPE; macrophage). This term pertains if there is an increase in the neuronal accumulation of lipofuscin (also known as autofluorescent lipoprotein) more than expected for the age of the patient." [HPO:probinson, pmid:11406682]

"Lipofuscin (age pigment) is a brown-yellow, electron-dense, autofluorescent material that accumulates progressively over time in lysosomes of postmitotic cells, such as neurons and cardiac myocytes.  This term pertains if there is an increase in the accumulation of lipofuscin (also known as autofluorescent lipoprotein) more than expected for the age of the patient." [HPO:probinson, pmid:9531959]

children.name: Senile plaques
is_a_string: HP:0007367 ! Atrophy/Degeneration affecting the central nervous system
children.defn: "Senile plaques are extracellular deposits of amyloid in the gray matter of the brain." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Recurrent meningitis
Recurrent bacterial meningitis
children.defn: "An increased susceptibility to bacterial meningitis as manifested by a medical history of recurrent episodes of bacterial meningitis." [HPO:probinson]
"An increased susceptibility to meningitis as manifested by a medical history of recurrent episodes of meningitis." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Meningitis
children.defn: "Inflammation of the meninges." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Brain abscess
children.defn: "A collection of pus, immune cells, and other material in the brain." []

is_a_string: HP:0002062 ! Morphological abnormality of the pyramidal tract

children.name: Corticospinal tract pallor
is_a_string: HP:0002492 ! Abnormality of the corticospinal tract

children.defn: "Abnormality of the corticospinal tract, which is the chief element of the pyramidal system (the principle motor tract) and is the only direct connection between the cerebrum and the spinal cord." [HPO:probinson]

"Any structural abnormality of the pyramidal tract, whose chief element, the corticospinal tract, is the only direct connection between the brain and the spinal cord. In addition to the corticospinal tract, the pyramidal system includes the corticobulbar, corticomesencephalic, and corticopontine tracts." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Abnormality of the subarachnoid space
is_a_string: HP:0002011 ! Morphological abnormality of the central nervous system

children.name: Widened subarachnoid space
is_a_string: HP:0012703 ! Abnormality of the subarachnoid space

children.name: Widened cerebral subarachnoid space
children.defn: "An increase in size of the anatomic space between the arachnoid membrane and pia mater in the region surrounding the cerebrum." [UToronto:htrang]

children.name: Widened cerebellar subarachnoid space
children.defn: "An increase in size of the anatomic space between the arachnoid membrane and pia mater in the region surrounding the cerebellum." [UToronto:htrang]
"An increase in size of the anatomic space between the arachnoid membrane and pia mater." [HPO:probinson]
"Abnormality in the space in the meninges beneath the arachnoid membrane and above the pia mater that contains the cerebrospinal fluid." [UToronto:htrang]
"A structural abnormality of the central nervous system." [HPO:probinson]

children.defn: "Delayed myelination in the peripheral nervous system." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Peripheral demyelination
Segmental peripheral demyelination/remyelination
children.defn: "A segmental pattern of demyelination and regeneration (remyelination) affecting peripheral nerves." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Diffuse peripheral demyelination
children.defn: "A diffuse loss of myelin from the internode regions along myelinated nerve fibers of the peripheral nervous system." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Symmetric peripheral demyelination
Symmetrical progressive peripheral demyelination
children.defn: "A symmetric and progressive loss of myelin from the internode regions along myelinated nerve fibers of the peripheral nervous system." [HPO:probinson]
"A symmetric loss of myelin from the internode regions along myelinated nerve fibers of the peripheral nervous system." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Segmental peripheral demyelination
children.defn: "A loss of myelin from the internode regions along myelinated nerve fibers from segments of the peripheral nervous system." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Asymmetric peripheral demyelination
children.defn: "Loss of myelin from peripheral nerves in a pattern that differs between right and left." [HPO:jbaets]
"A loss of myelin from the internode regions along myelinated nerve fibers of the peripheral nervous system." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Onion bulb formation
Basal lamina 'onion bulb' formation
children.defn: "A type of onion bulb formation prominently affecting the area of the basal lamina." [HPO:probinson]

"Repeated episodes of segmental demyelination and remyelination lead to the accumulation of supernumerary Schwann cells around axons, which is referred to as onion bulb formation. This finding affects peripheral nerves." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Decreased number of peripheral myelinated nerve fibers
Decreased number of large peripheral myelinated nerve fibers
is_a_string: HP:0003380 ! Decreased number of peripheral myelinated nerve fibers
children.defn: "A reduced number of large myelinated nerve fibers." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Decreased number of small peripheral myelinated nerve fibers
is_a_string: HP:0003380 ! Decreased number of peripheral myelinated nerve fibers

children.defn: "A loss of myelinated nerve fibers in the peripheral nervous system (in general, this finding can be observed on nerve biopsy)." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Peripheral hypomyelination
children.defn: "Reduced amount of myelin in the nervous system resulting from defective myelinogenesis in the peripheral nervous system." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Peripheral hypermyelination
Myelin outfoldings
children.defn: "The presence of excessive redundant myelin in the peripheral nerve sheath." [HPO:probinson, pmid:10932274]

children.name: Irregular myelin loops
children.defn: "Presence of irregular redundant loops of focally folded myelin in a peripheral nerve.\n\n" [pmid:20301641, pmid:8817346]

children.name: Myelin tomacula
children.defn: "The presence of multiple sausage-shaped swellings of the myelin sheath  (The Latin tomaculum means sausage)." [HPO:jbeats, pmid:10727485]

children.name: Increased peripheral myelin thickness
children.defn: "Elevated thickness of the myelin sheath of peripheral nerves, in a regular and concentric fashion." [HPO:jbeats]
"Increased amount of peripheral myelination." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Peripheral amyelination
children.defn: " Congenital absence of the myelin sheath on a nerve." [HPO:jbeats, pmid:22246888]

children.name: Peripheral dysmyelination
children.defn: "Defective structure and function of myelin sheaths. Dysmyelination is distinguished from demyleination where there is destruction or damage of previously normal myelination. " [HPO:probinson]
"An abnormality of the myelination of motor and sensory peripheral nerves. These are axons for motor nerves and dendrites for sensory nerves in the strict anatomic sense." [DDD:fmunitoni, HPO:jbaets]

children.name: Demyelinating peripheral neuropathy
Demyelinating sensory neuropathy
children.defn: "Demyelination of peripheral sensory nerves." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Acute demyelinating polyneuropathy
children.defn: "Acute progressive areflexic weakness and mild sensory changes resulting from myelin breakdown and axonal degeneration." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Demyelinating motor neuropathy
children.defn: "Demyelination of peripheral motor nerves." [HPO:probinson]
"Demyelinating neuropathy is characterized by slow nerve conduction velocities with reduced amplitudes of sensory/motor nerve conduction and prolonged distal latencies." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Delayed myelination
children.defn: "Delayed myelination." [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]
"Any anomaly in the process by which myelin sheaths are formed and maintained around neurons." [HPO:probinson, MP:0000920]

is_a_string: HP:0012639 ! Abnormality of nervous system morphology

children.name: Decreased size of nerve terminals

children.name: Hypertrophic nerve changes

is_a_string: HP:0000759 ! Abnormal peripheral nervous system morphology
children.defn: "Any anomaly of the anterior horn cell." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Abnormal lower motor neuron morphology
is_a_string: HP:0000759 ! Abnormal peripheral nervous system morphology
children.defn: "Any structural anomaly of the lower motor neuron." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Abnormality of peripheral nerves
is_a_string: HP:0000759 ! Abnormal peripheral nervous system morphology

children.name: Abnormality of peripheral nerve conduction
is_a_string: HP:0030177 ! Abnormality of peripheral nervous system electrophysiology

children.name: Abnormal nerve conduction velocity
is_a_string: HP:0003134 ! Abnormality of peripheral nerve conduction

children.name: Motor conduction block
is_a_string: HP:0040131 ! Abnormal motor nerve conduction velocity
children.defn: "Blockade of impulses at a focal site along the course of a motor axon." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Decreased motor nerve conduction velocity
is_a_string: HP:0040131 ! Abnormal motor nerve conduction velocity
children.defn: "A type of decreased nerve conduction velocity that affects the motor neuron." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Decreased sensory nerve conduction velocity
is_a_string: HP:0040132 ! Abnormal sensory nerve conduction velocity
children.defn: "Reduced speed of conduction of the action potential along a sensory nerve." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Decreased nerve conduction velocity
children.defn: "A reduction in the speed at which electrical signals propagate along the axon of a neuron." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Abnormal peripheral action potential amplitude
is_a_string: HP:0003134 ! Abnormality of peripheral nerve conduction

children.name: Decreased amplitude of sensory action potentials
is_a_string: HP:0030179 ! Abnormal peripheral action potential amplitude

children.name: Decreased distal sensory nerve action potential
is_a_string: HP:0007078 ! Decreased amplitude of sensory action potentials
children.defn: "A reduction in the amplitude of sensory nerve action potential in distal nerve segments. This feature is measured by nerve conduction studies." [HPO:probinson]
"A reduction in the amplitude of sensory nerve action potential. This feature is measured by nerve conduction studies." [HPO:probinson]
"An anomaly in the magnitude of the action potential along a peripheral nerve, that is, of the rapid rise and fall of the electrical membrane potential of the nerve." []
"An abnormality of the conduction of electrical impulses by peripheral (motor or sensory) nerves. This finding is elicited by a nerve conduction study (NCS)." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Enlarged peripheral nerve
children.defn: "Increase in size of a peripheral nerve. This finding can be appreciated by palpation along the axis of the nerve." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Peripheral axonal degeneration
is_a_string: HP:0000759 ! Abnormal peripheral nervous system morphology

children.name: Axonal loss
children.defn: "A reduction in the number of axons in the peripheral nervous system." [DDD:probinson]

children.name: Peripheral axonal atrophy
children.defn: "Atrophic changes of axons of the peripheral nervous system." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Axonal regeneration
Clusters of axonal regeneration
children.defn: "Groups of small caliber axons in peripheral nerve biospies indicative of axonal regeneration." [HPO:jbaets]
"The presence of axonal regeneration following a previous axonal lesion." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Peripheral axonal neuropathy
Motor axonal neuropathy
children.defn: "Progressive impairment of function of motor axons with muscle weakness, atrophy, and cramps. The deficits are length-dependent, meaning that muscles innervated by the longest nerves are affected first, so that for instance the arms are affected at a later age than the onset of deficits involving the lower leg." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Chronic axonal neuropathy
children.defn: "An abnormality characterized by chronic impairment of  the normal functioning of the axons." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Sensory axonal neuropathy
children.defn: "An axonal neuropathy of peripheral sensory nerves." [HPO:curators]
"An abnormality characterized by disruption of  the normal functioning of peripheral axons." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Axonal degeneration/regeneration
children.defn: "A pattern of simultaneous degeneration and regeneration of axons (see comment)." [HPO:probinson]
"Progressive deterioration of peripheral axons." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Enhanced neurotoxicity of vincristine
is_a_string: HP:0000759 ! Abnormal peripheral nervous system morphology

children.name: Peripheral neuropathy
is_a_string: HP:0000759 ! Abnormal peripheral nervous system morphology

children.name: Sensorimotor polyneuropathy affecting arms more than legs
Entrapment neuropathy
Entrapment neuropathy of suprascapular nerve
children.defn: "An entrapment neuropathy of the suprascapular nerve, presenting with shoulder weakness confined to the supraspinatus muscle (this muscle initiates shoulder abduction) or to the infraspinatus (this muscle externally rotates the arm), as well as with pain in the posterior part of the shoulder and upper periscapular region." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Entrapment neuropathy of the ulnar nerve at elbow
children.defn: "An entrapment neuropathy of the ulnar nerve in the cubital tunnel (in the elbow) characterized by numbness in the ring and little fingers and weakness of the intrinsic muscles in the hand." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Constrictive median neuropathy
children.defn: "Injury to the median nerve caused by its entrapment at the wrist as it traverses through the carpal tunnel. Clinically, constrictive median neuropathy is characterized by pain, paresthesia, and weakness in the median nerve distribution of the hand." [HPO:probinson]
"Malfunction of a peripheral nerve resulting from mechanical compression of the nerve roots from internal or external causes and leading to a conduction block or axonal loss." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Sensory impairment
Impaired tactile sensation
Impaired distal tactile sensation
children.defn: "A reduced sense of touch (tactile sensation) on the skin of the distal limbs. This is usually tested with a wisp of cotton or a fine camel's hair brush, by asking patients to say 'now' each time they feel the stimulus." [HPO:probinson]

"A reduced sense of touch (tactile sensation). This is usually tested with a wisp of cotton or a fine camel's hair brush, by asking patients to say 'now' each time they feel the stimulus." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Impaired proprioception
Sensory ataxia
children.defn: "Incoordination of movement caused by a deficit in the sensory nervous system. Sensory ataxia can be distinguished from cerebellar ataxia by asking the patient to close his or her eyes. Persons with cerebellar ataxia show only a minimal worsening of symptoms, whereas persons with sensory ataxia show a marked worsening of symptoms." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Positive Romberg sign
children.defn: "The patient stands with the feet placed together and balance and is asked to close his or her eyes. A loss of balance upon eye closure is a positive Romberg sign and is interpreted as indicating a deficit in proprioception." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Impaired distal proprioception
children.defn: "A loss or impairment of the sensation of the relative position of parts of the body and joint position occuring at distal joints." [HPO:probinson]
"A loss or impairment of the sensation of the relative position of parts of the body and joint position." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Dissociated sensory loss
children.defn: "A pattern of sensory loss with selective loss of touch sensation and proprioception without loss of pain and temperature, or vice-versa." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Impaired vibratory sensation
Impaired vibration sensation in the lower limbs
Impaired vibration sensation at ankles
is_a_string: HP:0002166 ! Impaired vibration sensation in the lower limbs
children.defn: "A decrease in the ability to perceive vibration at the ankles. Clinically, this is usually tested with a tuning fork which vibrates at 128 Hz and is applied to the malleoli of the ankles." [HPO:probinson]
"A decrease in the ability to perceive vibration in the legs." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Impaired distal vibration sensation
children.defn: "A decrease in the ability to perceive vibration in the distal portions of the limbs." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Abolished vibration sense
children.defn: "A complete loss of the ability to perceive vibration." [HPO:curators]

"A decrease in the ability to perceive vibration. Clinically, this is usually tested with a tuning fork which vibrates at 128 Hz and is applied to bony prominences such as the malleoli at the ankles or the metacarpal-phalangeal joints. There is a slow decay of vibration from the tuning fork. The degree of vibratory sense loss can be crudely estimated by counting the number of seconds that the examiner can perceive the vibration longer than the patient." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Abnormality of pain sensation
Spontaneous pain sensation
children.defn: "Spontaneous pain is a kind of neuropathic pain which occurs without an identifiable trigger." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Impaired pain sensation
Pain insensitivity
children.defn: "Inability to perceive painful stimuli." [HPO:probinson]
"Reduced ability to perceive painful stimuli." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Trophic changes related to pain
Trophic limb changes
is_a_string: HP:0010834 ! Trophic changes related to pain
children.defn: "Trophic changes occuring in a limb." [HPO:probinson]

"Trophic changes is a term used to describe abnormalities in the area of pain that include primarily wasting away of the skin, tissues, or muscle, thinning of the bones, and changes in how the hair or nails grow, including thickening or thinning of hair or brittle nails." [HPO:probinson]

"Pain is an unpleasant sensation that can range from mild, localized discomfort to agony, whereby the physical part of pain results from nerve stimulation and is often accompanied by an emotional component. This term groups abnormalities in pain sensation presumed to result from abnormalities related to the specific nerve fibers that carry the pain impulses to the brain." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Impaired temperature sensation
children.defn: "A reduced ability to discriminate between different temperatures." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Distal sensory impairment
children.defn: "An abnormal reduction in sensation in the distal portions of the extremities." [HPO:probinson]

"An abnormality of the primary sensation that is mediated by peripheral nerves (pain, temperature, touch, vibration, joint position). The word hypoesthesia (or hyesthesia) refers to a reduction in cutaneous sensation to a specific type of testing." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Sensory neuropathy
Distal peripheral sensory neuropathy
children.defn: "Peripheral sensory neuropathy affecting primarily distal sensation." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Distal sensory impairment of all modalities
Distal sensory loss of all modalities
is_a_string: HP:0003409 ! Distal sensory impairment of all modalities

children.name: Paresthesia
Dysesthesia
children.defn: "Abnormal sensations with no apparent physical cause that are painful or unpleasant." [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]
"Abnormal sensations such as tingling, pricking, or numbness of the skin with no apparent physical cause." [HPO:probinson]
"Peripheral neuropathy affecting the sensory nerves." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Mononeuropathy
children.defn: "A focal lesion of a single peripheral nerve. Damage to a sensory nerve is accompanied by sensory impairment of all modalities in the affected anatomic distribution." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Polyneuropathy
children.defn: "A generalized disorder of peripheral nerves." [HPO:curators]

"Peripheral neuropathy is a general term for any disorder of the peripheral nervous system. The main clinical features used to classify peripheral neuropathy are distribution, type (mainly demyelinating versus mainly axonal), duration, and course." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Abnormality of the cranial nerves
is_a_string: HP:0000759 ! Abnormal peripheral nervous system morphology

children.name: Abnormality of the vestibulocochlear nerve
is_a_string: HP:0001291 ! Abnormality of the cranial nerves
children.defn: "Abnormality of the vestibulocochlear nerve, the eighth cranial nerve, which is involved in transmitting sound and equilibrium information from the inner ear to the brain." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Cranial nerve motor loss
is_a_string: HP:0001291 ! Abnormality of the cranial nerves

children.name: Abnormality of the seventh cranial nerve
is_a_string: HP:0001291 ! Abnormality of the cranial nerves
children.defn: "Abnormality of the seventh cranial nerve sometimes also referred to as the facial nerve." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Abnormality of the twelfth cranial nerve
is_a_string: HP:0001291 ! Abnormality of the cranial nerves
children.defn: "Abnormality of the twelfth cranial nerve." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Abnormality of the eleventh cranial nerve
is_a_string: HP:0001291 ! Abnormality of the cranial nerves
children.defn: "Abnormality of the eleventh cranial nerve." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Abnormality of the fifth cranial nerve
is_a_string: HP:0001291 ! Abnormality of the cranial nerves

children.name: Trigeminal neuralgia
is_a_string: HP:0010824 ! Abnormality of the fifth cranial nerve
children.defn: "A neuropathic disorder characterized by episodes of intense pain in the face, originating from the trigeminal nerve. One, two, or all three branches of the nerve may be affected." [HPO:sdoelken]
"An abormality of the fifth cranial nerve." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Abnormality of the sixth cranial nerve
is_a_string: HP:0001291 ! Abnormality of the cranial nerves

children.name: Abducens palsy
is_a_string: HP:0011348 ! Abnormality of the sixth cranial nerve
children.defn: "Malfunction of the abducens nerve as manifested by impairment of the ability of the affected eye to be moved outward." [HPO:probinson]
"An abnormality of the abducens nerve." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Cranial nerve paralysis
is_a_string: HP:0001291 ! Abnormality of the cranial nerves

children.name: Fourth cranial nerve palsy
children.defn: "Paralysis of the fourth cranial (trochlear) nerve manifested as weakness of the superior oblique muscle which causes vertical diplopia that is maximal when the affected eye is adducted and directed inferiorly." [ORCIRD:0000-0001-5208-3432]

children.name: Cranial nerve compression
is_a_string: HP:0001291 ! Abnormality of the cranial nerves

children.defn: "Abnormality affecting one or more of the cranial nerves, which emerge directly from the brain stem." [HPO:probinson]

"An abnormality of the peripheral nervous system, which is composed of the nerves that lead to or branch off from the central nervous system. This includes the cranial nerves (olfactory and optic nerves are technically part of the central nervous system)." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Abnormal neuron morphology
is_a_string: HP:0012639 ! Abnormality of nervous system morphology

children.name: Abnormal motor neuron morphology
Paucity of anterior horn motor neurons
Abnormal upper motor neuron morphology
children.defn: "Any structural anomaly that affects the upper motor neuron." []
"Any structural anomal that affects the motor neuron." []
"A structural anomaly of a neuron." [KI:phemming]

children.name: Abnormality of the autonomic nervous system
is_a_string: HP:0012639 ! Abnormality of nervous system morphology

children.name: Abnormal autonomic nervous system morphology
is_a_string: HP:0002270 ! Abnormality of the autonomic nervous system
children.defn: "A structural abnormality of the autonomic nervous system." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Abnormal autonomic nervous system physiology
is_a_string: HP:0002270 ! Abnormality of the autonomic nervous system

children.name: Orthostatic tachycardia
is_a_string: HP:0012332 ! Abnormal autonomic nervous system physiology
children.defn: "An increase in heart rate with standing of 30 beats per minute or more." [HPO:probinson, pmid:9244228]

children.name: Dysautonomia
is_a_string: HP:0012332 ! Abnormal autonomic nervous system physiology

children.name: Autonomic bladder dysfunction
children.defn: "Abnormal bladder function (increased urge or frequency of urination or urge incontinence) resulting from abnormal functioning of the autonomic nervous system." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Autonomic erectile dysfunction
children.defn: "Impotence (inability to develop or maintain an erection) resulting from abnormal functioning of the autonomic nervous system." [HPO:probinson]
"Dysfunction of the autonomic nervous system." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Autonomic dysregulation
is_a_string: HP:0012332 ! Abnormal autonomic nervous system physiology
children.defn: "An abnormality of the regulation of the autonomic nervous system." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Abnormal sudomotor regulation
is_a_string: HP:0012332 ! Abnormal autonomic nervous system physiology
children.defn: "An abnormal regulation of the sweat glands by the sympathetic nervous system associated with abnormal perspiration." [HPO:probinson]
"A functional abnormality of the autonomic nervous system." [HPO:probinson]
"An abnormality of the autonomic nervous system." [HPO:probinson]
"A structural anomaly of the nervous system." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Abnormality of nervous system physiology
is_a_string: HP:0000707 ! Abnormality of the nervous system

children.name: Abnormality of movement
is_a_string: HP:0012638 ! Abnormality of nervous system physiology

children.name: Clonus
Knee clonus
children.defn: ".Clonus is an involuntary tendon reflex that causes repeated flexion and extension of the foot. Knee clonus can be tested by rapidly pushing the patella towards the toes." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Elbow clonus
children.defn: "Clonus at the elbow joint, i.e., an  exaggerated phasic stretch reflex characterized by repetitive, rhythmic contractions at the elbow, generated by rapid passive stretch at the elbow joint." [HPO:probinson]
"A series of rhythmic and involuntary muscle contractions (at a frequency of about 5 to 7 Hz) that occur in response to an abruptly applied and sustained stretch." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Hypokinesia
children.defn: "Abnormally diminished motor activity. In contrast to paralysis, hypokinesia is not characterized by a lack of motor strength, but rather by a poverty of movement. The typical habitual movements (e.g., folding the arms, crossing the legs) are reduced in frequency." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Akinesia
children.defn: "Inability to initiate changes in activity or movement and to perform ordinary volitional movements rapidly and easily." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Tics
Phonic tics
children.defn: "Involuntary sounds produced by moving air through the nose, mouth, or throat. The vocal cords are not involved in all tics that produce sound." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Motor tics
children.defn: "Movement-based tics affecting discrete muscle groups." [HPO:sdoelken]
"A tic is a sudden, repetitive, nonrhythmic, stereotyped motor movement or vocalization involving discrete muscle groups." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Head titubation
children.defn: "A head tremor of moderate speed (3 to 4 Hz) in the anterior-posterior direction." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Cerebral palsy
is_a_string: HP:0011442 ! Abnormality of central motor function

children.name: Athetoid cerebral palsy
is_a_string: HP:0002071 ! Abnormality of extrapyramidal motor function
children.defn: "A type of cerebral palsy characterized by slow, involuntary muscle movement and mixed muscle tone." [DDD:ssissodiya]

"Cerebral palsy describes a group of permanent disorders of the development of movement and posture, causing activity limitation, that are attributed to nonprogressive disturbances that occurred in the developing fetal or infant brain. The motor disorders of cerebral palsy are often accompanied by disturbances of sensation, perception, cognition, communication, and behaviour, by epilepsy, and by secondary musculoskeletal problems." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Dyskinesia
Extrapyramidal dyskinesia
is_a_string: HP:0002071 ! Abnormality of extrapyramidal motor function

children.defn: "A movement disorder which consists of effects including diminished voluntary movements and the presence of involuntary movements." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Myokymia
children.defn: "Successive and rapid contractions of motor units associated with chronic nerve injury. The discharges arise from the peripheral aspects of regenerating nerves, and clinically impart a nearly continuous undulation of the body surface overlying the muscle." [HPO:probinson, MeSH:D020385]

children.name: Bimanual synkinesia
children.defn: "Mirror hand movements." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Tremor
Resting tremor
children.defn: "A resting tremor occurs when muscles are at rest and becomes less noticeable or disappears when the affected muscles are moved. Resting tremors are often slow and coarse." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Action tremor
Postural tremor
Upper limb postural tremor
children.defn: "A type of tremors that is triggered by holding an arm in a fixed position." [HPO:probinson]
"A type of tremors that is triggered by holding a limb in a fixed position." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Kinetic tremor
Intention tremor
children.defn: "A type of kinetic tremor that occurs during target directed movement is called intention tremor. That is, an oscillatory cerebellar ataxia that tends to be absent when the limbs are inactive and during the first part of voluntary movement but worsening as the movement continues and greater precision is required (e.g., in touching a target such as the patient's nose or a physician's finger)." [HPO:probinson, pmid:16344298]
"Tremor that occurs during any voluntary movement. It may include visually or non-visually guided movements. Tremor during target directed movement is called intention tremor." []

children.name: Titubation
Truncal titubation
children.defn: "Tremor of the trunk in an anterior-posterior plane at 3-4 Hz." [HPO:probinson]
"Nodding movement of the head or body." [HPO:probinson, pmid:4821687]

children.name: Isometric tremor
children.defn: "An isometric tremor occurs with muscle contraction against a rigid stationary object (e.g., when making a fist)." [HPO:probinson, pmid:21404980]

children.name: Vocal tremor
children.defn: "A wavering, unsteady voice that reflects involuntary and approximately sinusoidal oscillation of motor unit firings of laryngeal muscles. Vocal tremor results in low frequency modulations of voice frequency or amplitude and intermittent voice instability." [HPO:probinson, pmid:22505778]
"A tremor present when the limbs are active, either when outstretched in a certain position or throughout a voluntary movement." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Tremor by anatomical site
Head tremor
children.defn: "An unintentional, oscillating to-and-fro muscle movement affecting head movement." [HPO:probinson]
"Tremor classified by the affected body part." [HPO:probinson]
"An unintentional, oscillating to-and-fro muscle movement." [HPO:probinson, pmid:16344298]

children.name: Dystonia
Paroxysmal dystonia
children.defn: "A form of dystonia characterized by episodes of dystonia (often hemidystonia or generalized) lasting from minutes to hours. There are no dystonic symptoms between episodes." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Limb dystonia
children.defn: "A type of dystonia (abnormally increased muscular tone causing fixed abnormal postures) that affects muscles of the limbs." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Oculogyric crisis
children.defn: "An acute dystonic reaction with blepharospasm, periorbital twitches, and protracted fixed staring episodes. There may be a maximal upward deviation of the eyes in the sustained fashion. Oculogyric crisis can be triggered by a number of factors including neuroleptic medications." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Axial dystonia
children.defn: "A type of dystonia that affects the midline muscles, i.e., the chest, abdominal, and back muscles." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Generalized dystonia
children.defn: "A type of dystonia that affects all or most of the body." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Focal dystonia
Craniofacial dystonia
Oromandibular dystonia
children.defn: "A kind of focal dystonia characterized by forceful contractions of the face, jaw, and/or tongue causing difficulty in opening and closing the mouth and often affecting chewing and speech." [HPO:probinson]
"A form of focal dystonia affecting the face, head or neck muscles." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Writer's cramp
children.defn: "A focal dystonia of the fingers, hand, and/or forearm that appears when the affected person attempts to do a task that requires fine motor movements such as writing or playing a musical instrument." [HPO:probinson]
"A type of dystonia that is localized to a specific part of the body." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Torsion dystonia
children.defn: "Sustained involuntary  muscle contractions that produce twisting and repetitive movements of the body." [HPO:probinson]

"An abnormally increased muscular tone that causes fixed abnormal postures. There is a slow, intermittent twisting motion that leads to exaggerated turning and posture of the extremities and trunk." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder
children.defn: "Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) manifests at age 2-3 years or by first grade at the latest. The main symptoms are distractibility, impulsivity, hyperactivity, and often trouble organizing tasks and projects, difficulty going to sleep, and social problems from being aggressive, loud, or impatient." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Abnormal posturing
children.defn: "Involuntary flexion or extension of the arms and legs." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Muscle fibrillation
children.defn: "Fine, rapid twitching of individual muscle fibers with little or no movement of the muscle as a whole. If a motor neuron or its axon is destroyed, the muscle fibers it innervates undergo denervation atrophy. This leads to hypersensitivity of individual muscle fibers to acetyl choline so that they may contract spontaneously. Isolated activity of individual muscle fibers is generally so fine it cannot be seen through the intact skin, although it can be recorded as a short-duration spike in the EMG." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Gait disturbance
Broad-based gait
children.defn: "An abnormal gait pattern in which persons stand and walk with their feet spaced widely apart. This is often a component of cerebellar ataxia." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Tip-toe gait
children.defn: "An abnormal gait pattern characterized by the failue of the heel to contact the floor at the onset of stance during gait." [pmid:24757457]

children.name: Steppage gait
children.defn: "An abnormal gait pattern that arises from weakness of the pretibial and peroneal muscles due to a lower motor neuron lesion. Affected patients have footdrop and are unable to dorsiflex and evert the foot. The leg is lifted high on walking so that the toes clear the ground, and there may be a slapping noise when the foot strikes the ground again." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Inability to walk
Loss of ability to walk in early childhood
is_a_string: HP:0006915 ! Inability to walk by childhood/adolescence

children.name: Loss of ability to walk in first decade

children.defn: "Incapability to ambulate." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Gait apraxia
children.defn: "Gait apraxia affecting the ability to make walking movements with the legs." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Gait instability, worse in the dark
Scissor gait
children.defn: "A form of gait abnormality characterized by hypertonia and flexion in the legs, hips and pelvis accompanied by extreme adduction leading to the knees and thighs hitting, or sometimes even crossing, in a scissors-like movement. The opposing muscles (abductors) become comparatively weak from lack of use." [HPO:probinson]

"The term gait disturbance can refer to any disruption of the ability to walk. In general, this can refer to neurological diseases but also fractures or other sources of pain that is triggered upon walking. However, in the current context gait disturbance refers to difficulty walking on the basis of a neurological or muscular disease." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Hyperkinesis
children.defn: "Motor hyperactivity with excessive movement of muscles of the body as a whole." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Asterixis
children.defn: "A clinical sign indicating a lapse of posture and is usually manifest by a bilateral flapping tremor at the wrist, metacarpophalangeal, and hip joints." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Frontal release signs
children.defn: "Primitive reflexes traditionally held to be a sign of disorders that affect the frontal lobes." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Involuntary movements
Myoclonus
Spinal myoclonus
children.defn: "Spinal myoclonus is generally due to a tumor, infection, injury, or degenerative process of the spinal cord, and is characterized by involuntary rhythmic muscle contractions, usually at a rate of more than one per second. Myoclonus occurs synchronously in several muscles and can be increased in severity and frequency by fatigue or stress, but is usually unaffected by sensory stimuli. Spinal myoclonus ceases during sleep or anesthesia." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Palatal myoclonus
children.defn: "Palatal myoclonus is characterized by myoclonic (rhythmic involuntary jerky) movements of the soft palate." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Sleep myoclonus
children.defn: "Myoclonus that occurs during the initial phases of sleep." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Hemifacial spasm
children.defn: "A segmental myoclonus of muscles innervated by the facial nerve." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Chin myoclonus
children.defn: "Involuntary and irregular twitches of the chin." [HPO:probinson, pmid:16816905]
"Very brief, involuntary random muscular contractions occurring at rest, in response to sensory stimuli, or accompanying voluntary movements." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Fasciculations
Limb fasciculations
children.defn: "Fasciculations affecting the musculature of the arms and legs." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Facial-lingual fasciculations
children.defn: "Fasciculations affecting the tongue muscle and the musculature of the face." [HPO:curators]

"Fasciculations are observed as small, local, involuntary muscle contractions (twitching) visible under the skin. Fasciculations result from increased irritability of an axon (which in turn is often a manifestation of disease of a motor neuron). This leads to sporadic discharges of all the muscle fibers controlled by the axon in isolation from other motor units." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Chorea
Choreoathetosis
Paroxysmal choreoathetosis
children.defn: "Episodes of choreoathetosis that can occur following triggers such as quick voluntary movements." [HPO:probinson]
"Involuntary movements characterized by both athetosis (inability to sustain muscles in a fixed position) and chorea (widespread jerky arrhythmic movements)." [HPO:probinson]
"Chorea (Greek for 'dance') refers to widespread arrhythmic involuntary movements of a forcible, jerky and restless fashion." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Athetosis
children.defn: "Athetosis (from the Greek word for 'changeable' or 'unfixed') refers to an inability to sustain the muscles of the fingers, toes, tongue, or any other group of muscles in a fixed position. Instead, posture is interrupted by slow, purposeless involuntary movements." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Self-mutilation of tongue and lips due to involuntary movements
Intermittent painful muscle spasms
children.defn: "History of repeated intermittent involuntary muscle contractions that were painful." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Paroxysmal dyskinesia
children.defn: "Episodic bouts of involuntary movements with dystonic, choreic, ballistic movements, or a combination thereof. There is no loss of consciousness during the attacks." [HPO:probinson]
"Involuntary contractions of muscle leading to involuntary movements of extremities, neck, trunk, or face." [HPO:probinson]
"An abnormality of movement with a neurological basis characterized by changes in coordination and speed of voluntary movements." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Pseudobulbar signs

children.name: Pseudobulbar behavioral symptoms
children.defn: "Individuals with Pseudobulbar signs often also demonstrate abnormal behavioral symptoms such as inappropriate emotional outbursts of uncontrolled laughter or weeping etc." [HPO:sdoelken]

"Pseudobulbar signs result from injury to an upper motor neuron lesion to the corticobulbar pathways in the pyramidal tract. Patients have difficulty chewing, swallowing and demonstrate slurred speech (often initial presentation) as well as abnormal behavioral symptoms such as inappropriate emotional outbursts of uncontrolled laughter or weeping etc." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.defn: "An abnormality of somatosensory evoked potentials (SSEP), i.e., of the electrical signals of sensation going from the body to the brain in response to a defined stimulus. Recording electrodes are placed over the scalp, spine, and peripheral nerves proximal to the stimulation site. Clinical studies generally use electrical stimulation of peripheral nerves to elicit potentials. SSEP testing determines whether peripheral sensory nerves are able to transmit sensory information like pain, temperature, and touch to the brain. Abnormal SSEPs can result from dysfunction at the level of the peripheral nerve, plexus, spinal root, spinal cord, brain stem, thalamocortical projections, or primary somatosensory cortex." [HPO:curators]

This is a four step process, comprising (i) synthesis and storage of neurotransmitters; (ii) neurotransmitter release; (iii) activation of postsynaptic receptors by the neurotransmitter; and (iv) inactivation of the neurotransmitter. Thus, this term is defined as an anomaly of neurotransmitter metabolic process." [HPO:probinson, MP:0003635]

children.name: Echolalia
children.defn: "The tendency to repeat vocalizations made by another person." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Dysgraphia
children.defn: "A writing disability in the absence of motor or sensory deficits of the upper extremities, resulting in an impairment in the ability to write regardless of the ability to read and not due to intellectual impairment." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Alexia
children.defn: "An acquired type of sensory aphasia where damage to the brain leads to the loss of the ability to read." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Deficit in nonword repetition
children.defn: "Impaired ability to repeat non-word sounds. Nonword repetition (NWR) is a measure of short-term phonological memory." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Apraxia
is_a_string: HP:0011442 ! Abnormality of central motor function
HP:0011446 ! Abnormality of higher mental function

children.name: Speech apraxia
children.defn: "A type of apraxia that is characterized by difficulty or inability to execute speech movements because of problems with coordination and motor problems, leading to incorrect articulation. An increase of errors with increasing word and phrase length may occur." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Limb apraxia
children.defn: "Difficulty in performing the correct execution of limbs movements  in absence of motor impairment." [ICM:PCaroppo]
"A defect in the understanding of complex motor commands and in the execution of certain learned movements, i.e., deficits in the cognitive components of learned movements." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Reduced consciousness/confusion
is_a_string: HP:0011446 ! Abnormality of higher mental function

children.name: Drowsiness
Paroxysmal drowsiness
children.defn: "Attacks of disabling daytime drowsiness and low alertness." [HPO:probinson]
"Excessive daytime sleepiness." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Confusion
children.defn: "Lack of clarity and coherence of thought, perception, understanding, or action." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Lethargy
Paroxysmal lethargy
children.defn: "Repeated episodes of sudden-onset and transient lethargy." [HPO:probinson]
"A state of  disinterestedness, listlessness, and indifference, resulting in difficulty performing simple tasks or concentrating." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Coma
children.defn: "Complete absence of wakefulness and content of conscience, which manifests itself as a lack of response to any kind of external stimuli." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Agnosia
is_a_string: HP:0011446 ! Abnormality of higher mental function

children.name: Visual agnosia
children.defn: "Difficulty in recognizing objects by visual input in absence of sensorial visual impairment." [ICM:PCaroppo]

children.name: Prosopagnosia
children.defn: "Inability to recognize faces of familair persons." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Astereognosia
is_a_string: HP:0011730 ! Abnormality of central sensory function
children.defn: "Inability to recognize the form of objects by touch without visual input. That is, an impairment in the recognition of objects based only on based on the texture, size, weight and three-dimensional form of the object in the absence of any major somatosensory deficit." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Finger agnosia
children.defn: "An inability or difficulty differentiating among the fingers of either hand as well as the hands of others." [HPO:curators]

"Inability to recognize objects not because of sensory deficit but because of the inability to combine components of sensory impressions into a complete pattern. Thus, agnosia is a neurological condition which results in an inability to know, to name, to identify, and to extract meaning from visual, auditory, or tactile impressions." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Cognitive impairment
is_a_string: HP:0011446 ! Abnormality of higher mental function

children.name: Mental deterioration
Progressive language deterioration
children.defn: "Progressive loss of previously present language abilities." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Psychomotor deterioration
children.defn: "Loss of previously present mental and motor abilities." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Dementia
Subcortical dementia
children.defn: "A particular type of dementia characterized by a pattern of mental defects consisting prominently of forgetfulness, slowness of thought processes, and personality or mood change." [HPO:probinson, pmid:4819905]

children.name: Frontotemporal dementia
Semantic dementia
children.defn: "A progressive loss of the ability to remember the meaning of words, faces and objects." [ICM:PCaroppo, pmid:24966676]

"A dementia associated with degeneration of the frontotemporal lobe and clinically associated with personality and behavioral changes such as disinhibition, apathy, and lack of insight. The hallmark feature of frontotemporal dementia is the presentation with focal syndromes such as progressive language dysfunction, or aphasia, or behavioral changes characteristic of frontal lobe disorders. " [HPO:probinson, pmid:24966676]

"A loss of global cognitive ability of sufficient amount to interfere with normal social or occupational function. Dementia represents a loss of previously present cognitive abilities, generally in adults, and can affect memory, thinking, language, judgment, and behavior." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Motor deterioration
children.defn: "Loss of previously present motor (i.e., movement) abilities." [HPO:probinson]
"Loss of previously present mental abilities, generally in adults." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Memory impairment
Transient global amnesia
children.defn: "A paroxysmal, transient loss of memory function with preservation of immediate recall and remote memory but with a severe impairment of memory for recent events and ability to retain new information." [HPO:curators]
"An impairment of memory as manifested by a reduced ability to remember things such as dates and names, and increased forgetfulness." [HPO:probinson]
"Abnormality in the process of thought including the ability to process information." [HPO:sdoelken]
"Cognitive, psychiatric or memory anomaly." [DDD:ajackson]

children.name: Bulbar signs
is_a_string: HP:0012638 ! Abnormality of nervous system physiology

children.name: Sleep disturbance
is_a_string: HP:0012638 ! Abnormality of nervous system physiology

children.name: Bruxism
children.defn: "Bruxism is characterized by the grinding of the teeth including the clenching of the jaw and typically occur during sleep." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Abnormal rapid eye movement (REM) sleep
children.defn: "Abnormality of REM sleep. Phases of REM sleep are characterized by desynchronized EEG patterns, increases in heart rate and blood pressure, sympathetic activation, and a profound loss of muscle tonus except for the eye and middle-ear muscles. There are then phases of rapid eye movements." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Sleep apnea
Central sleep apnea
children.defn: "Sleep apnea resulting from a transient abolition of the central drive to the ventilatory muscles." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Obstructive sleep apnea
children.defn: "A condition characterized by obstruction of the airway and by pauses in breathing during sleep occurring many times during the night. Obstructive sleep apnea is related to a relaxation of muscle tone (which normally occurs during sleep) leading to partial collapse of the soft tissues in the airway with resultant obstruction of the air flow." [HPO:probinson]

"An intermittent cessation of airflow at the mouth and nose during sleep. Apneas of at least 10 seconds are considered important, but persons with sleep apnea may have apneas of 20 seconds to up to 2 or 3 minutes. Patients may have up to 15 events per hour of sleep." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Narcolepsy
children.defn: "An abnormal phenomenon characterized by a classic tetrad of excessive daytime sleepiness with irresistible sleep attacks, cataplexy (sudden bilateral loss of muscle tone), hypnagogic hallucination, and sleep paralysis." []

children.name: Restless legs
children.defn: "A feeling of uneasiness and restlessness in the legs after going to bed (sometimes causing insomnia)." [HPO:probinson]

"An abnormality of sleep including such phenomena as 1) insomnia/hypersomnia, 2) non-restorative sleep, 3) sleep schedule disorder, 4) excessive daytime somnolence, 5) sleep apnea, and 6) restlessness." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Neurodevelopmental abnormality
is_a_string: HP:0012638 ! Abnormality of nervous system physiology

children.name: Developmental regression
children.defn: "Loss of developmental skills, as manifested by loss of developmental milestones." [DDD:hvfirth]

children.name: Specific learning disability
Dyscalculia
children.defn: "A specific learning disability involving mathematics and arithmetic." [DDD:probinson]

children.name: Impaired visuospatial constructive cognition
children.defn: "Reduced ability affecting mainly  visuospatial cognition which may be tested using pattern construction (for example by Differential Ability Scales, which test a person's strengths and weaknesses across a range of intellectual abilities)." [HPO:sdoelken, pmid:10521286]

children.name: Dyslexia
children.defn: "A learning disorder characterized primarily by difficulties in learning to read and spell. Dyslectic children also exhibit a tendency to read words from right to left and to confuse letters such as b and d whose orientation is important for their identification. Children with dyslexia appear to be impaired in phonemic skills (the ability to associate visual symbols with the sounds they represent)." [HPO:probinson]

"Impairment of certain skills such as reading or writing, coordination, self-control, or attention that interfere with the ability to learn. The impairment is not related to a global deficiency of intelligence." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Intellectual disability
Intellectual disability, profound
children.defn: "Profound mental retardation is defined as an intelligence quotient (IQ) below 20." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Intellectual disability, severe
children.defn: "Severe mental retardation is defined as an intelligence quotient (IQ) in the range of 20-34." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Intellectual disability, progressive
children.defn: "The term progressive intellectual disability should be used if intelligence decreases/deteriorates over time." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Intellectual disability, borderline
children.defn: "Borderline intellectual disability is defined as an intelligence quotient (IQ) in the range of 70-79." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Intellectual disability, moderate
children.defn: "Moderate mental retardation is defined as an intelligence quotient (IQ) in the range of 35-49." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Intellectual disability, mild
children.defn: "Mild intellectual disability is defined as an intelligence quotient (IQ) in the range of 50-69." [HPO:probinson]

"Subnormal intellectual functioning which originates during the developmental period. Intellectual disability, previously referred to as mental retardation, has been defined as an IQ score below 70." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Delayed speech and language development
Receptive language delay
is_a_string: HP:0000750 ! Delayed speech and language development

children.name: Severe receptive language delay
children.defn: "A severe delay in the acquisition of the ability to understand the speech of others." [DDD:hvfirth]

children.name: Mild receptive language delay
children.defn: "A mild delay in the acquisition of the ability to understand the speech of others." [DDD:hvfirth]

children.name: Moderate receptive language delay
children.defn: "A moderate delay in the acquisition of the ability to understand the speech of others." [DDD:hvfirth]
"A delay in the acquisition of the ability to understand the speech of others." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Expressive language delay
is_a_string: HP:0000750 ! Delayed speech and language development

children.name: Severe expressive language delay
children.defn: "A severe delay in the acquisition of the ability to use language to communicate needs, wishes, or thoughts." [DDD:hvfirth]

children.name: Moderate expressive language delay
children.defn: "A moderate delay in the acquisition of the ability to use language to communicate needs, wishes, or thoughts." [DDD:hvfirth]

children.name: Mild expressive language delay
children.defn: "A mild delay in the acquisition of the ability to use language to communicate needs, wishes, or thoughts." [DDD:hvfirth]
"A delay in the acquisition of the ability to use language to communicate needs, wishes, or thoughts." [HPO:probinson]
"A degree of language development that is significantly below the norm for a child of a specified age." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Delayed social development
children.defn: "A failure to meet one or more age-related milestones of social behavior." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Global developmental delay
Profound global developmental delay
children.defn: "A profound delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child." [DDD:hvfirth]

children.name: Mild global developmental delay
children.defn: "A mild delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child." [DDD:hvfirth]

children.name: Moderate global developmental delay
children.defn: "A moderate delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child." [DDD:hvfirth]

children.name: Severe global developmental delay
children.defn: "A severe delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child." [DDD:hvfirth]

"A delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child, including motor skills, speech and language, cognitive skills, and social and emotional skills. This term should only be used to describe children younger than five years of age." [DDD:hvfirth, HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Motor delay
Delayed fine motor development
children.defn: "A type of motor delay characterized by an delay in acquiring the ability to control the fingers and hands." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Delayed gross motor development
children.defn: "A type of motor delay characterized by an delay in acquiring the ability to control the large muscles of the body for walking, running, sitting, and crawling." [HPO:probinson]
"A type of Developmental delay characterized by a delay in acquiring motor skills." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Developmental stagnation
Developmental stagnation at onset of seizures
children.defn: "A cessation of the development of a child in the areas of motor skills, speech and language, cognitive skills, and social and/or emotional skills, following the onset of epilepsy." [HPO:probinson]
"A cessation of the development of a child in the areas of motor skills, speech and language, cognitive skills, and social and/or emotional skills." [HPO:probinson]

"A deviation from normal of the neurological development of a child, which may include any or all of the aspects of the development of personal, social, gross or fine motor, and cognitive abilities." [KI:phemming]

children.name: Abnormality of central sensory function
is_a_string: HP:0012638 ! Abnormality of nervous system physiology

children.name: Impaired touch localization
is_a_string: HP:0011730 ! Abnormality of central sensory function
children.defn: "A reduced ability to identify precisely the site of a touch. This test is usually carried out by asking a patient, whose eyes are closed or covered, to touch the same site with a fingertip." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Impaired two-point discrimination
is_a_string: HP:0011730 ! Abnormality of central sensory function
children.defn: "A reduced ability to distinguish tactile sensations at points that are very close to one another. This can be tested by using special calipers whose points can be set from 2mm to several centimeters apart." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Agraphesthesia
is_a_string: HP:0011730 ! Abnormality of central sensory function
children.defn: "Impaired ability to recognize letters or numbers drawn by an examiner's fingertip on the patient's skin (the patients eyes are closed or covered throughout this examination)." [HPO:probinson]

"An abnormality of cortical sensation. Assuming the primary sensory modalities are intact and the patient is alert and cooperative, the presence of an abnormality of sensory function usually indicates a lesion of a parietal cortex or of the thalamocortical projections to the parietal cortex." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Abnormality of intracranial pressure
is_a_string: HP:0012638 ! Abnormality of nervous system physiology

children.name: Increased intracranial pressure
children.defn: "An increase of the pressure inside the cranium (skull) and thereby in the brain tissue and cerebrospinal fluid." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Decreased intracranial pressure
children.defn: "A reduction of the pressure inside the cranium (skull) and thereby in the brain tissue and cerebrospinal fluid." [HPO:probinson]
"A deviation from the norm of the intracranial pressure." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Pain
is_a_string: HP:0012638 ! Abnormality of nervous system physiology

children.name: Chronic pain
children.defn: "Persistent pain, usually defined as pain that has laster longer than 3 to 6 months." [HPO:probinson, pmid:1875958]

children.name: Allodynia
children.defn: "Pain due to a stimulus that does not normally provoke pain." [HPO:probinson]
"An unpleasant sensory and emotional experience associated with actual or potential tissue damage, or described in terms of such damage." [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]

children.name: Behavioral abnormality
is_a_string: HP:0012638 ! Abnormality of nervous system physiology

children.name: Fatigue
Chronic fatigue
children.defn: "Subjective feeling of tiredness characterized by a lack of energy and motivation that persists for six months or longer." [ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]

children.name: Episodic fatigue
children.defn: "Intermittent and recurrent bouts of a subjective feeling of tiredness characterized by a lack of energy and motivation." [HPO:probinson]
"A subjective feeling of tiredness characterized by a lack of energy and motivation." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Abnormal emotion/affect behavior
Abnormal aggressive, impulsive or violent behavior
Aggressive behavior
is_a_string: HP:0006919 ! Abnormal aggressive, impulsive or violent behavior
children.defn: "Aggressive behavior can denote verbal aggression, physical aggression against objects, physical aggression against people, and may also include aggression towards oneself." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Violent behavior
is_a_string: HP:0006919 ! Abnormal aggressive, impulsive or violent behavior

children.name: Impulsivity
is_a_string: HP:0006919 ! Abnormal aggressive, impulsive or violent behavior

children.name: Self-injurious behavior
is_a_string: HP:0006919 ! Abnormal aggressive, impulsive or violent behavior

children.name: Skin-picking
children.defn: "Repetitive and compulsive picking of skin which results in tissue damage." [HPO:probinson, pmid:20575652]

children.name: Hair-pulling
children.defn: "A phenomenon in which persons repetitively pull out their own hair, resulting in noticeable hair loss." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Head-banging
children.defn: "Habitual striking of one's own head against a surface such as a mattress or wall of a crib." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Self-biting
Nail-biting
children.defn: "Habitual biting of one's own fingernails." [HPO:probinson]
"Habitual biting of one's own body." [HPO:probinson]
"Aggression towards oneself." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Anhedonia
children.defn: "Inability to experience pleasure  activities usually found enjoyable." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Abnormal fear/anxiety-related behavior
Anxiety
children.defn: "Feeling or dread, apprehension, and impending disaster." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Agoraphobia
children.defn: "A type of anxiety disorder characterized by avoidance of public places, especially where crowds gather." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Mood swings
children.defn: "An exaggeration of emotional affects such as laughing crying, or yawning beyond what the person feels." [HPO:curators]
"An abnormality of fear/anxiety-related behavior, which may relate to either abnormally reduced fear/anxiety-related response or increased fear/anxiety-related response." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Conspicuously happy disposition
children.defn: "An unusually happy aspect over time which can also may be observed during inappropriate situations that should be causing for example distress, fear or anger." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Depression
children.defn: "A condition characterized by pervasive dysphoric mood, loss of interests, and inability to experience pleasure." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Emotional blunting
children.defn: "Lack of emotional reactivity and empathy for situations or persons, sometime also for family members." [ICM:PCaroppo]

children.name: Diminished motivation
Inertia
children.defn: "Reduction of goal-directed behaviors linked to the impairment in frontal executive functions (planning of an action for example)." [ICM:PCaroppo]

children.name: Akinetic mutism
children.defn: "Akinetic mutism is essentially characterized by a total absence of spontaneous behavior and speech occurring in the presence of preserved visual tracking." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Apathy
children.defn: "Lack of emotion or emotional expression; a disorder of motivation that persists over time." [MeSH:D057565]

children.name: Abulia
children.defn: "Poverty of behavior and speech output, lack of initiative, loss of emotional responses, psychomotor slowing, and prolonged speech latency." [HPO:probinson, pmid:16030444, UToronto:HTrang]

"A reduction in goal-directed behavior, that is, motivation, the determinant of behavior and adaptation that allows individuals to get started, be energized to perform a sustained and directed action." [HPO:probinson, pmid:16030444]
"An abnormality of emotional behaviour." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Phonophobia
children.defn: "An abnormally heightened sensitivity to loud sounds." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Delusions
Paranoia
children.defn: "A persecutory delusion of supposed hostility of others." [HPO:probinson]
"A belief that is pathological and is held despite evidence to the contrary." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Schizophrenia
children.defn: "A mental disorder characterized by a disintegration of thought processes and of emotional responsiveness. It most commonly manifests as auditory hallucinations, paranoid or bizarre delusions, or disorganized speech and thinking, and it is accompanied by significant social or occupational dysfunction. The onset of symptoms typically occurs in young adulthood, with a global lifetime prevalence of about 0.3-0.7%." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Oppositional defiant disorder
children.defn: "An enduring pattern of uncooperative, defiant, and hostile behavior toward authority figures that does not involve major antisocial violations, is not accounted for by the child's developmental stage, and results in significant functional impairment. A certain level of oppositional behavior is common in children and adolescents." [DSM:313.81, HPO:probinson]

children.name: Perseveration
children.defn: "Perseveration can be defined as the contextually inappropriate and unintentional repetition of a response or behavioral unit. In other words, the observed repetitiveness does not meet the demands of the situation, is not the product of deliberation, and may even unfold despite counterintention. Perseveration can therefore be differentiated from goal-directed and intentional forms of repetition, such as linguistic redundancies designed to enhance communicative or poetic impact." [HPO:probinson, pmid:9050113]

children.name: Personality disorder
Borderline personality disorder
children.defn: "A personality disorder characterized by impulsive behavior and unpredictable and capricious mood. Affected individuals show a liability to outbursts of emotion and an incapacity to control the behavioural explosions." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Histrionic personality disorder
children.defn: "A personality disorder characterized by shallow and labile affectivity, self-dramatization, theatricality, exaggerated expression of emotions, suggestibility, egocentricity, self-indulgence, lack of consideration for others, easily hurt feelings, and continuous seeking for appreciation, excitement and attention." [ICD-10:F60.4]

"An abnormality of mental functioning affecting the personality and behavioural tendencies of an individual and characterized by a rigid and unhealthy pattern of thinking and behavior. The definition of a personal disorder implies that the abnormality is not the result of damage or insult to the brain or from another psychiatric disorder." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Hallucinations
children.defn: "Perceptions in a conscious and awake state in the absence of external stimuli which have qualities of real perception, in that they are vivid, substantial, and located in external objective space." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Inflexible adherence to routines or rituals
Short attention span
children.defn: "Reduced attention span characterized by distractibility and impulsivity but not necessarily satisfying the diagnostic criteria for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder." [HPO:curators]

children.name: Hypersexuality
children.defn: "Pathological persistent sexual disinhibiting behavior, directed  at oneself or to others." [ICM:PCaroppo]

children.name: Socially inappropriate behavior
children.defn: "Behavior that is not in line with social norms." [ICM:PCaroppo]

children.name: Disinhibition
children.defn: "A lack of restraint manifested in several ways, including disregard for social conventions, impulsivity, and poor risk assessment." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Inappropriate crying
children.defn: "Uncontrolled episodes of crying, without apparent motivating stimuli." [ICM:PCaroppo]

children.name: Hyperorality
children.defn: "A tendency or compulsion to examine objects by mouth." [HPO:sdoelken]

children.name: Personality changes
children.defn: "An abnormal shift in patterns of thinking, acting, or feeling." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Abnormal social behavior
Impaired social reciprocity
children.defn: "A reduced ability to participate in the back and forth flow of social interaction, which is normally characterized by an influence of the behavior of one person on the behavior of another person who is in conversation with the first." [KI:phemming]

children.name: Impaired social interactions
Poor eye contact
children.defn: "Difficulty in looking at another person in the eye." [HPO:probinson]

children.name: Impaired use of nonverbal behaviors
